data.alt: Pelta Games- Play Art Play. SPE - thoskite | ello
1970s, completing undergrad gra - thoskite | ello

body.data: During the 1970s, while completing undergrad and grad Art programs in Printmaking, created a series of creatures 1st based on Dante's Inferno. They started to branch out along lines that were a response to ideas of the time around the growing field of Recombinant DNA. There was also a longstanding fascination w/ the fossil record in general and lymnology in particular. Last, in the mix is life drawing and anatomy studies filtered thru haunting experiences in the operating room as a part-time scrub nurse. And out came this drawing which was then made into an engraving and intaglio printed, but never editioned. Yet, it did kick off a lasting love affair w/ glass as it became the design for the 1st glass acid etching. Called them Metatarsus Hominid from the human feet and an idea that these creatures came from either the very distant past or future or both. Or in an alternate universe where dinosaurs were never wiped out, they are the present day incredibly advanced result of a much longer span of evolution- a race of meta-saurs. The metasaur drawing about an unlikely creature sprinting across Time seemed to take on a more melancholy tone until recently. Now, it's become apparent it was, all along, directly connected to something always entirely new in a place where past, present and future are meaningless. This connection required an update presenting it as the ancient forerunner of yet another wave of alternative creatures. The image above started as a scan of the original drawing made over 40 years ago, but then devolved accordingly. Related: Saying goodbye @elloartgiveaways @ellomakers @ello @ellowrites

body.data: @ellomakers - These 9 hotshop cast art glass pieces were made in 2006. They vary in size from 5" to 6" in diameter x 2" to 4" thick and were coldworked to increase their proclivity to rock gently back and forth. This shot shows them on a glass table 42" long. They're a set that was referred to as BoneRiver, but that didn't cut it so they remained untitled. Yesterday, it became clear they are PeltaBones?! Thought they were about kinectic stuff for more than 10 yrs, but they weren't. That was just something they did for laughs. Didn't get it so they waited. data.alt: Tessellation Fugue VII variatio - thoskite | ello

body.data:
"Tessellation Fugue VII" is another variation on a game art design. And another riff on color counterpoint within repeating Pelta patterns. This one decided to add relief and push the flats. The Pelta comes from a primeval design of 2 circles whose diameters equal the radius of the 3rd circle they inhabit. This motif can be found in one form or another everywhere throughout human history from ancient Thracian shields to Roman mosaics, Celtic art / book illumination and so on up to this moment. 

Like a circle in a spiral
Like a wheel within a wheel
Never ending or beginning
On an ever-spinning reel
As the images unwind
Like the circles that you find
In the windmills of your mind
-Dusty Springfield

data.alt: - design concepts hard satisfy - thoskite | ello

body.data: @ellomakers - Some design concepts are hard to satisfy. 8 Studies in Symmetry is one. With an aesthetic chip on their shoulder they started out as the most symmetric geometric primitive of all- a circle. Then came peltas. Then copy/rotation formed wireframe globes. Next followed arcane, self imposed rules of deconstruction by color, attempting to prove/disprove the old line that color destroys form. Multiple goes at it yielded damn little, but had interestingly different stopping points spawning versions of versions winnowed down to 8. In 2013, these demanded more and became a series of anims. But playing in the 4th dimension left them still digital which wasn't enough. So a year ago, they were UV printed on 12x12" Baltic birch panels, put in plain black frames, and hung. That lasted less than a year. Nothing's less satisfying than being nailed to a wall. Next came an unfortunate try at being interactive as 2 sided, laser cut jigsaw puzzles. As bad as that went, there still was the urge to 3D. They had to be touched, picked up, and fondled. Who doesn't? really. Now here they are, hopefully happy- Nine, 2" birch wood cubes, UV printed on all 6 sides with 6 of the original 8 Studies in Symmetry. They're free to form their original designs, mingle, or stand alone in a chaotic universe where digital, analog, 2D, and 3D are one. Started not as glass, not even analog- but wanted more... https://youtu.be/sMlF-VqRjMk #gameart #puzzle #uncarvedblock #gamesarttk #sculpture3Dtk @theshapesyndicate @ellowrites

data.alt: glass Hotshop, sand cast block  - thoskite | ello

body.data:
This glass Hotshop, sand cast block is part of a series called "Memes" done a while ago. It's roughly 8 x 8 x 4" and weighs around 15 lbs. The process was orchestrated to work the forms in a way that's a metaphor for the Darwinian struggle ideas have waged by human proxy throughout history. Molten glass flooded the forms in the sand mold and subsumed them. The cobalt glass rod didn't even have time to shatter nor the copper to heat patina (oxidize). Both adapted and persist changed, but unchanged. The struggle endures. 
More process details in the vid below-

data.alt: 2 weeks 8 Studies Symmetry outg - thoskite | ello

body.data: It took just 2 weeks for 8 Studies in Symmetry to outgrow the mere 3D as UV printed wood blocks. It may be because there's a concept in 3D CNC machining to describe what's really sculpting in space and is hard to make sense of at 1st. It goes sort of this way- The 3 dimensions of space- width, length, and height, can be mapped on 3 axes- X, Y, and Z. However, a 3 axis CNC machine can't make complex shapes that have undercuts or hollow out compound curve objects or a number of other things unless more axes are used. That's because the material's orientation to the machine doesn't change. If you add 2 more axes you have a 5 axis CNC machine that can do all these things. But 5 axes in space sounds like nonsense- the 4th dimension is time and there is no 5th dimension, excepting The Age of Aquarius and in advanced math. But, those 2 extra axis on a CNC are possible by just adding rotation to 2 of the original 3- X, Y, and Z axes. This allows the material being carved to move in relation to the shaping tool. It's a way to describe a much more complex tool cutting path that takes time to traverse- like paths in 2D and 3D animation. All this could've made 8 Studies in Symmetry have to be more than just static 3D, but still remain analog uncarved blocks. Why make it easy? Fortunately, glass knows all about that kind of thing because that's what transparent objects do best- change constantly. They do it prismatically when viewed from different angles and instantly by reflecting environment changes of even the most subtle nature. So here are Nine 2" clear acrylic cubes, UV printed w/ the same 6 designs as the wood blocks. But, instead of printing all 6 sides- only 3 adjacent sides are printed. Each side is- reverse printed with 1 design, then 3 layers of white, and finally the 2nd design. 1 design faces in and the other faces out. Inward facing designs are seen thru the transparent, unprinted sides. They're free to be 2D, 3D, animate, and inanimate as their patterns morph, multiply, change hue, or form new 3D shapes in a chaotic universe where not even nonlocal causality can explain how quantum objects behave. And they can get handled doing it, too! But are they now happy at last? Well, sort of... Update: these blocks were lost in the hurricane, but just made a new set (6/2020) with a new UV printer (same model as the one destroyed in 2018).

data.alt: glass. Sea People - set kiln fo - thoskite | ello

body.data:
More about glass. Sea People - is a set of kiln formed & fire polished 3/4x3/4" bar stock cut on a diamond wet-saw from heavy float plate glass. The bars were lightly cold worked before forming so the fire polish would give the ground surfaces more sparkle. 

The last post mentioned the ability of glass to absorb its surroundings. Here the dark winter branches in weak December sun are as much a part of Sea People as bright sky blues and Maple leaf deep greens are on a clear summer's day. All's filtered thru a pale green tint from iron impurities found in float glass, shifting to cooler sea tones, every passing hue. 

In daylight, Sea People can be delightfully quixotic. And even in darkest night, they find stray photons to plot and glimmer with. Some hop from the porch light down the street. Others from starlight 100s of years streaking across the galaxy. And there's always the inconstant Moon.

data.alt: PeltaPeeps ancient MemeMech Pel - thoskite | ello

body.data: PeltaPeeps used the ancient MemeMech they found on PelStar to test shields on their new V2 MemeMechs. They always get a real c h a r g e out of blasting stuff. So did the Grand Watch Tower because the testing set off the Tower’s alarm system- kaBoom! Nothing like 100 GiGAwatt ball of fire to brighten your day. Of course the lightning was fun too… even it wasn’t planned on. But, while the energy seen here looks familiar- it’s not what you think. In the Worlds of Peltan, things are very different. For instance, these Mechs are amplifying psychokinetic powers of the PeltaPeep pilots to generate incredibly intense Meme Pulses much like super lasers on Earth focus light into concentrations of enormous destructive power. (see video below) The ancient MemeMech on the left is blasting the new V2 Mech at point blank range with enough disruption to completely obliterate the old Mech if the tables were turned. The 1st blast is deflected by the V2’s armor alone causing next to no damage. The remaining blasts are completely neutralized by the V2’s active shields. Result- near zero damage. The new units are far tougher than expected. When PeltaPeeps set about to make something, they do it more than right because there’s an old Peltragon saying- “too much is never enough!” More at MemeMech playlist

data.alt: game art spun work PeltaDrome 3 - thoskite | ello

body.data: This is game art spun off work for PeltaDrome our 3rd game. And it's the 1st to take baby steps toward really tapping into the promise of the Pelta in terms of game mechanics. That promise is- Peltas can be thought of as the ultimate continuous game board! This is because circles have a special property, in that they have an infinite number of angles as points of intersection, and minimal surface area. The implication is more 3D-like possibilities in a 2D surface. More at- The Pelta and Game Mechanics And made into a GIF anim because they add push to 2D ... like to follow the crosses around & nice to watch listening to Clash's - Should I Stay or Should I Go... kinda existential indecision stuff. enjoy-

data.alt: 'Origami Tess' designs lets Sta - thoskite | ello

body.data: 'Origami Tess' is another one of those designs that lets you know there's more to be done until you get it right. Starting in 2008 from the ancient labyrinth seed, a tessellating set of boxes sprung to life. But contrary to life's labyrinth, there was no entrance or exit. Later, the design was developed for laser engraving glass panels (a set of 17) for an entertainment wall. A 2nd related stair railing project took that idea and folded the tessellations into different shapes of complimentary manifolds. But, these manifold manifolds weren't satisfied. So after flirting with color unsuccessfully, they demanded a bit of movement- a place in time as it were. So here they are- messing around with Moiré patterns in real time. data.alt: Making, maker finds polyamorous - thoskite | ello

body.data: When it comes to Making, this maker finds a polyamorous approach the most fertile ground for growing objects, images, language, ideas, design & maybe art. It's come at a cost because that runs counter to Art Establishment protocols which demand a marketable sameness to create brand recognition. Neither is it very responsive to trends du jour as the logic of what drives it is- the chaotic, cross fertilization in embracing all things as tools to birth yet another unique actor within the fractal of this life. Kinda a mouthful... huh ...well then there's this other thing- With time, it's harder to equate Making with what gets made. And the urge to credit the maker grows especially difficult to understand. Like crediting a passing cloud for a heart rending moonrise, it's an embarrassing conflation. What becomes has its own existential trajectory, independent of its maker. Both being so is wonder and consolation.
Olduvai - stone sculpture overseen by a blind strigiforme (negative image of a copper plate engraved intaglio print)
PeltaPeeps - game art fooling around in the dark
Inorganic Relations - coldworked & battuto engraved bottle glass (wine, bourbon, & cognac sacrificed to the muses)

New V2 MemeMech - PeltaPeeps character 3D game art stuff About me - been around a long time making stuff. Payed dues, but overall been pretty lucky. data.alt: Pelta Games font unruly. jumped - thoskite | ello

body.data:
The Pelta Games font is truly unruly. It jumped from a quick stab at squeezing peltas into type to logo as visual pun. Only then did the bright idea to make it a downloadable font seem a bit of doable fun. That turned out akin to kicking a skunk.

It's just not the way to produce a font. They don't take kindly to anything less than abject devotion to their sacred place in the design firmament. In other words, making letters is a hoot. But getting the relationships and spacing to turn out uppercase, lowercase, italic, bold, semibold, light, narrow + special chars - is as far from trivial as it gets. 

In the universe of Font, one can boldly go where hoards have gone before or -  
k e r n   from one's mistakes...

But why GIF it? In the interests of full disclosure- took a dose of "Here I Go Again" by Whitesnake (the 1987 version- below) while workin on it. A lone wolf kinda woof thing and we're all running outa time. So screw the details and just do it. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Gin-l4LDdXQ

data.alt: Printers special relationship b - thoskite | ello

body.data: Printers have a special relationship with black. And the richest, deepest, velvety kind of all comes from mezzotint. Made back in the day, this mezzotint is from a series of studies for Dante's Inferno. Its copper printing plate was prepared by hand in the traditional manner using a 100 tooth per inch mezzotint rocker- 2.5 inches wide. The rocking was done holding the rocker at the correct angle to raise a carpet of burrs in the plate by advancing the rocker, a line at a time, in the direction of the smooth side of the tool. Yet a recent review of online videos shows mezzotint rockers being used rocking consistently in the wrong direction. Either the physics of engraving copper has changed or backwards results hold enough ink to be currently acceptable. The Inferno plate was printed using hand ground ink with a touch of clove oil to suit it better to this sort of printing. Editioned at only 15 prints, most were lost over the years. Backlisted by circumstance and chance, they keep company with other survivors in a zippered portfolio as time flows through them. But, now the cat's out of the bag in a room full of mezzotint rockers. This print was rocked in a grossly iconoclastic manner by today's standards. Surely it's as much a Black-listable offense as any bestowed by what the fates allow. Fortunately, students of the inferno know darkness has its moments-

Thanks! Love the black on black negative space in your Circle loading-

Never been a fan of conceptual art- avoided it successfully for as long and as much as possible. But it finally caught up. So going to take a page out of that book and mention take-aways on article about Adrian Piper having never even heard of her until the NYT piece by Hsiag-Ron Cheng. Think of this response to all unseen work she's done over her lifetime as its own conceptual art aka heard it from a friend who heard it from a friend who..., all fell in the meme forest and the internet wasn't around to hear, would they make the sound of silence*? Take-aways: with this caveat- below are responses/commentary about the article, not to be confused with an understanding of the artist's work. > Letting race or gender or anything else define you is a zero sum game. And it diverts precious time from making- possibly one of the highest and best uses of it in the race to die human. > As paranoid nuts as it sounds- Wellesley and institutions of their ilk are not your friend as they're predisposed to dispose of things that interfere with their will to power. By extension, this includes de facto constructs like the Art establishment. And let's not leave out government especially in places like the now former USA and USSR. > Giving up sex and then talking about giving it up is not giving up sex. A pivotal element of sex is anticipation. And another is recollection. Talking about sex is both. And talking about giving it up is totally sexy because of where that goes. Imagine how many kilowatts a horny person on a treadmill could generate in an hour then multiply that by 10 years! Think an entire small town lit up by the power of sex diverted into clean, but sweaty energy. data.alt: design started tessellating pat - thoskite | ello

body.data: This design started with a tessellating pattern created for laser engraving 17 glass panels in an entertainment wall. The latest version adds smokey rings to wireframe spheres interacting with the tessellation and each other in a predictable yet irregular manner. They may invoke the absorption of Emerson's transparent eye or more ominously, those of Dr. T. J. Eckleburg- amid the ashes of eroding worlds. Or the same time-lapse world awash in periodic waves of disruption. Or nothing more than a linear toccata to amuse the beholder. The above explanation started innocently enough, but quickly descended into an exercise in pompous overkill resulting in the murder of any interest and/or joy that such an image may have once been able to impart. But being based on tessellation, it can take from its creator as much crap as the faithful have from theirs and still survive if not thrive. And so the object outgrows its maker. data.alt: GIF 1 clock. takes 2 seconds wo - thoskite | ello

body.data:
This GIF is a 1 second clock. It actually takes 2 seconds to make that work in a looping GIF. Using the Time concept of interval vs. instant, it relies on the way your mind works to signal what a second is. Of course, there're 86,400 seconds in an average solar day (24 hours). Knowing that doesn't do much to experience what a second feels like though. Here's where interval and instant do their stuff. 

The GIF sweeps around the circle design in the interval of 1 second. It stops for an instant. Then starts another 1 second interval going around again. In Time theory, an instant is only a point in time. It's unmeasurable because it has no duration. A Time interval is what's between 2 instants. Its duration can be measured in Time because it has a beginning and an end (2 instants). 

This sneaky GIF cheats by stopping the animation for 1 second to give the illusion of an instant between each 1 second interval of sweep...

It gets worse.  26 frames make up this anim and the one above it. 25 of these display for an interval of about 1/25th of a second each. Your mind collects all these flashes into a smooth motion going one way or the other round the circle. The direction of spin is based on the order the frames appear in. Reverse the frame order and the spin appears to go backwards. No smoke or mirrors- just stringing images together in a set of time intervals that seen individually, are too short to notice...

And this last GIF's playing with half and quarter seconds interrupted by 2 - one second instants in a 3 second loop just because. The half seconds are sweeps and the quarters are background jumps. All 3 GIFs are saying something pretty involved about Time because they pause motion in intervals to simulate instants in a cycle of one kind or another. Cycles are like instants- uninterrupted, they have no beginning or end. So do circles. Think about it- instants have no past or future- only a Now. Or maybe the past and future are collapsed in now- the present- in an instant. Our brains are wired to constantly compare the past to the present, trying to predict the future. But, there are ways we can step out of Time into the instant of the present. Making is one of those where the mind can let go and only the present matters. There are others. Related post: A matter of time #ScienceFriday #Science @ello @ellodesign @ellomakers @ellowrites @elloblog @elloart #art #design #designer #makers @theneuralhouse #writerspot #geometry #geometricart #abstractart #abstract #GIF #time #future #past #present #vote Vote
Submitted to [Ello Artist Invite: Science Friday Reads Stephen Hawking](https://ello.co/artist-invites/science-friday-reads-stephen-hawking)

data.alt: 36 60, cast art glass panel 1 t - thoskite | ello

body.data: Here's a 36 x 60", cast art glass panel 1 inch thick that weights a bit over 200 lbs. It took about 80 hours in a computer controlled kiln to very slowly cool. Programmed temperature ranges, carefully staged, let the molten glass shrink from 1,500 degrees Fahrenheit to a stable, stress free panel at room temp. Those 4 days and nights several winter storms hit Seattle. That it survived the power outages is nothing short of miraculous. This glimmering thing that blithely sidestepped the Pacific ocean's discontent, appeared unscathed. Yet, its true nature took some time to realize. So strangely, while there obviously was real magic here, no one got it... at 1st. With the addition of an ordinary wood base, it chose to become a magic table rather than some overgrown objet d'art. Then posing as mere furniture, it went to work opening eyes to all fey goings on in simple everyday things starting with breakfast. Everything tasted better, meals less hurried, and games lively when seated round that sly Magic Table. Morning light was crisp and evening candles gave seductive shivers of warmth. The table was really laying it on thick. Well one night, when everyone's guard had left the room, it pounced on its maker with what it really had up its sleeve- make more magic stupid. It's pretty embarrassing when something as simple as that eludes you for so very long. Immediately followed by- how in hell? ...well pilgrim ...think ...don't you ...have ...a Magic Table now? Apparently, sarcasm is part of the package. Video w/ special appearance by the Magic Table (below)-

data.alt: couple days dog knocked Flash g - thoskite | ello

body.data:
A couple of days ago the dog knocked this Flash glass engraving off a window sill and it shattered. It was a test piece and old friend cut from a handmade sheet of French flash glass that was an extravagance to buy at the time. Ruby colors in glass are made with either Selenium or Gold. This kind of exotic glass has a very thin layer of color "flashed" on top of a base of clear or other color. It's especially suited to engraving because the cuts can be done on the flash side- removing the thin layer to reveal the base in striking contrast.  
In the mid '80s, this test piece was engraved using the traditional stone wheel method to "warm up" before making a duplicate to a broken pane from an old Civil War Museum in New England. Bordering some of the windows in the museum, there were 2 colors of engraved flash glass panels- cobalt blue on clear and ruby on clear- likely as a patriotic touch. Recall standing there in a musty room looking at the glass. In the stillness, sunlight cast red and blue on a worn wood floor, mixing like blood and water. In a slow whisper, it spoke only of unspeakable cost in lives and heartbreak.    

Later, the test engraving didn't really lend itself to making anything from it, but was kept as a technical benchmark and also as connection to an indelible moment. Working with glass you get accustomed to loss on a very much smaller scale- often work disappearing suddenly in shards. If you don't- you switch to another medium. So, it's funny how such a small thing as throwing out the remains of an old test piece can wound so.

Photo of engraved ruby Flash glass duplicate ready for installation (below)
thank you- guess it took that piece breaking to find the words

@stoicmike Thanks. Actually, think it was living on borrowed time because over a year ago an oak right across the street was hit by lighting. The next morning found this all in one piece, relaxing on the floor about 3 ft from the window. Figure the concussion from the house shaking thunder clap had made the window act like a drum head and bounced the engraving leaning against it, off the sill- to make a perfect 3-point landing flat on the wood floor.

Guess the universe doesn't take kindly to things that dodge its bullets. Or the karma of what it had been associated with, caught up with it...

data.alt: 1st drypoint Intaglio print pri - thoskite | ello

body.data:
This was 1st a drypoint Intaglio print printed from a copper plate. Working from a sketch of an elf owl, the drypoint- a form of engraving, was done in reverse using a sharp steel tool in a fashion much like drawing with pencil, but with more down force into the plate surface. The steel tip creates a groove and a bur of cut/displaced copper with each mark made. While groove and bur both hold ink, it's the bur that gives drypoint the distinctive softness of line. However, the bur crushes under the pressure of the press when editioning, so drypoint editions are small. This one was only 11 prints before the paper image started to degrade. Later, a variation of the design with no eyes, was done as an engraving for a print series about the Inferno, but never editioned. 

Elf owls are the smallest owl in North America- about the size of a sparrow. They live in the US southwest and Mexico where their population's decreasing. They're listed as endangered in California. 

No surprise there... unfortunately.

Original print below (done when putting your name on things still mattered)-

data.alt: '88/89, anim, lost, called Cong - thoskite | ello

body.data: Around '88/89, made an anim, since lost, called "Congrats". It was done on an Amiga 500 that was pumped up with a Fat Agnus graphics chip. The regular Agnus could address 1/2 MB of chip RAM. Fat Agnus doubled that being billed as making smoother cooler hiRes (640×400) animation possible. Had to cut a trace on the motherboard and do a little soldering which was intimidating. Damned if it didn't work though. Times then weren't great either existentially or otherwise. But the Traveling Wilburys' 1st album came out which was, and still is, great for the soul. Congratulations was 1 of the many songs on it we listened to a lot. The lost anim included some of that tune because it was partly its inspiration. The 1 posted here is the same as the old original in theme, only updated in style- not substance. Does use a 2008 NASA earth image they title, "Hurricane Alley". 30 years ago, everyone wanted a global climate treaty to deal with climate change. In the US, we the people wanted it. Our congress - both parties- wanted it. Our president promised it. But, it was derailed by insatiable greed in the form of short term profit. Then the disinformation ramped up to divide and conquer... If we the people still want a habitable world for our children, we must stand together to take back our sovereignty- now. Start with voting.

data.alt: TornSo hammered scrap copper sh - thoskite | ello

body.data:
TornSo was hammered out of a scrap of copper sheet and colorfully heat patinaed with an acetylene torch. The base is ground/polished, brass billet. 

The original base was hardwood painted black- no money for brass then. It was made facing a wall by hands working blind in a studio the size of a walk-in closet next to a cathouse on Old Town San Diego's desert shore. 

20 years later there was money for brass. The old patina's tarnished colors were all gone to dull brown. A light polish removed much of it, back to a hue of muted vindication. 

Seems objects are stronger and more patient than their makers. Old photos collage of the torso- below

Latest cut goes roughly like this- Theme: Aquatic civil war and dinnertime in the dystopian future right around the corner. Object: Fish eat fish for waterworld domination while "losing it". Game Environment: Board consists of the 7 super seas- land masses, toxic waste floating islands, and extreme weather events restrict/block movement- so global like a kind of waterworld Risk. A good bit of each continent is underwater due to global warming/climate change/fake news/empty pews. Backstory: Redfish and Blufish are an admixture of devolved lemmings and formerly 2 legged pond scum with implants, all now adapted back to the aquatic life in a matrix that's fully connected by Wi-Fin. Game Mechanics based on: • Redfish eat votes and Blufish. • Blufish eat granola and Redfish. • Both eat their young. • All eat Redfish and Blufish that get along. • Blufish have problems swimming in schools. • Redfish have problems swimming anywhere there aren't Redfish. • Both sink in the Sea of Reason. • Aliens (players) place side bets on who will win and throw chum in the form of discord memes to hedge their funz. • Players must chant aloud, "1 fish 2 fish", when taking a turn or lose it (the turn that is). Losing it repeatedly helps, but it takes a lot more than losing it to win it. And you may ask yourself...

data.alt: JS Bach Interface Translations - thoskite | ello

body.data:
JS Bach & Interface Translations-
Looking at art in terms of interface translations can be a valuable path to deeper meaning. It also can be a distraction from the original art. On distraction grounds- it ceases to meet the value add bar because it does little to inform. Take for example,  2 visualizations of one of the most powerful and indescribable pieces of music ever created- Toccata & Fugue in D minor. Look at them from an interface POV. The third example involves Bach's Crab Canon. 

The interface translations here are from auditory to visual. They get a huge boost from the music accompaniment and lose meaning standing alone. When you look at things from this perspective it's interesting to note that art criticism is a kind of interface translation from visual, performing or other art to print. Writing is a symbolic interface as opposed to the others which are sensory and therefore it can cheat by invoking sensory memories of analogs via connecting ideas. That's why it's the critic's weapon of choice- it can be used on anything.   

So if interfaces are meant to give access to or enhance/augment information or experience (information in a broader sense), then 2 of the visualizations below succeed. The other not so much. Spoiler- the 1 that's most successful is the one PeltaPeeps love. 

Toccata and Fugue Metal (Visualization Test) by GhostXb
Off the Staff by Nicholas Rougeux
Crab Canon on a Möbius Strip by Jos Leys

data.alt: Process Stuff II - prototype ga - thoskite | ello

body.data: Process Stuff II - prototype game art and pieces used a 7 step work flow (below) with combinations of materials and printing/cutting setups generating different Look & Feel. 1. The game art is initially created as a nested layout in vector file format using Corel Draw software. 2. 2 different files are exported for print and cutting. 3. Print is further adjusted/converted in Photoshop and updated with registration marks that are more visible on the laser bed. 4. That finished print PNG file is setup on the UV printer and the designs printed on acrylic sheet (prior to laser cutting). Software there and on the machine itself, is used to: .................. a. extend CMYK color space with additional white & varnish inks, .................. b. build up ink layers in printer software settings, .................. c. set UV curing modes and printer head/substrate gaps, .................. d. locate the job footprint on printer table prior to print. 5. The Cutting file (from step 2), is sent to another computer connected to a 150 watt laser machine. Software there and on the machine itself, is used to: .................. a. set up cutting mode job (laser can engrave or cut or do both), .................. b. focus the laser for the substrate thickness of .125", .................. c. adjust power/speed settings for cutting acrylic, and .................. d. locate the job footprint on the laser bed- prior to cutting parts. 6. Pre-printed parts sheet is placed on the laser bed and registered to the design by eye using an alignment red-dot beam simulating a registration cut path that matches the printed registration lines. 7. Last, the laser cuts out the PeltaPeeps playing pieces, the off-cut substrate's removed, and 48 finished parts are collected from the bed. The selection of the final version from all the different prototypes was based on aesthetics- 1st, total play tester response- 2nd, and cost to produce- 3rd. The winner from 3 finalists, turned out to be layered black and white design, one-side printed on solid color acrylic sheet. Long before that, half a dozen sizes were created and played with during rules dev and testing. Getting the process worked out was pretty cool, but nothing compared to seeing kids and adults getting into it at the public play tests- running fingers over the pieces, balancing one on another, fiddling around with them while figuring their next move. Remember in particular the WOW look on a 3rd grader's face when he got his hands on the acrylic. The wood ones were cool, but those acrylic- laser polished edges, smooth, hard, and precise...little ink ridges...the fit one to another... Doesn't get any better than that- a thing that feels good to turn over in your hand and mind all at once. Process Stuff I Example of nested layout below (reduces laser cut time and saves on material)-

data.alt: designs embed psyche early age  - thoskite | ello

body.data:
Some designs embed themselves in your psyche at an early age and are loved at a distance throughout life. They are met in books, museums, nature, and a hundred other ways, but usually remain at arm's length, unrequited. Yet, to understand is to feel, not just hear or see or read about. The non-digital needs to be felt, touched, tasted... and if you're very lucky- lived with. 

Living with these things shouldn't be confused with owning which has its own problems. They may seem to be owned, but none ever are. And many of them by the nature of their beauty, actually require stewardship.

For example- a V12 cylinder Series III, E-Type 2+2 Jaguar in British Racing Green with sparkling chrome tailpipes and a stick shift is no less than a kinetic work of Art. It's also an exacting mistress. Experience with a dozen Triumphs and MGs confirmed that taking on stewardship of any old British sports car, let alone the epitome of the genera, is nontrivial to the point of being hardcore masochism.  

But in the fog of long unattainable childhood dreams suddenly possible, caution isn't just thrown to the wind. No, it's the sky opening as paradise pours down amid unicorns squirting rainbows of exquisite joy out their bums to wipe out every last shred of sense.   

So, in the late 90's for $12,000 that damn dream came to life with the growl of a tired old steel cat. And right then, its reality was light years ahead of anything imaginable. Of course, it didn't matter that this 27 year old XKE was all original with 29,000 miles- code for little used garage queen. It would need everything to be a daily driver. But, that's the only scenario that made it possible so the impossible is a little harder. So what.  

Stewardship started day one with washing and waxing the jag. Running a hand over its sensuous curves, gently rubbing healing wax on what's left of the spent lacquer, in some places so thin the primer showed faintly as mild washing made it bleed British Racing Green all over the road. Hands learned of a sculpture in need of restoration. But, that could wait as this inanimate, elegant form magically took flight with luck and the turn of a key. The faint odor of mildewed leather, oil, and gasoline turned to vaguely sweet perfume each time the engine warmed up, the hand choke was pushed in, and the road howled.

8 years flew by, going to work before 5 am so no one's around to notice a green blur with pale yellow eyes on the straightaway of Lake Washington floating bridge. That was only after some baby steps. 1st, the fuel filter, full of reddish sand from its former home- New Mexico, needed changing after being towed home. Then tires for safety which meant new stainless steel wire wheels to replace the nasty steel ones. And so it went, every year or 2 another system updated to new- suspension, engine rebuild, the 4 carburetors redone, new leather, and so on.    

Until the day there was a another birth of Venus. A gleaming jag rolled out of the paint booth in flawless British Racing Green high-tech paint, infinitely superior to what it was born with in 1973. Even the dazzled body shop guys were moved to tears of adoration as the sun suddenly shone, angels sang, and blue birds of happiness shat on all the other cars, but not one splat on that sublime shape. They too knew.   

Unfortunately, stewardship means the best for what's being served. The time was getting nearer that the jag would need a frame off restoration. And being kept in a garage wouldn't hurt. So with hollow heart, a good home was found where a super anal engineer type could afford to continue. 

Having served such imperfect perfection is as good as any feeling to have when the acceleration of life reaches terminal velocity- to wink out or explode into space.
Want to thank all the sexbots in advance for the loves...
@pokalupsis yep- sexbots Just wrap your legs round these velvet rims And strap your hands across my engines-

@mikacuervo 90 mph in 2nd gear at the red line because too much is never enough. old C5 corvettes don't have the class, but they make up for it in take-your-breath-away performance and they are still affordable.

data.alt: Olduvai started stone sculpture - thoskite | ello

body.data:
Olduvai started as a stone sculpture- 12x7x6" overall. It's always wanted to be bronze and about 25 years later got the chance. 2 of the bronze version have been cast- the latest just last year. So now 3 exist including the original stone. 

The idea came from Homo erectus fossil remains found in Olduvai Gorge. It's a site in Tanzania that's produced the earliest evidence of what can be called humans.

The polished stone is a more powerful object in many ways, but the dual museum and mirror finish bronze really captures the fossil like patina with a creepy allusion to robotics and where we're headed. Or not. 

Have always seen this work as a maquette for at least a 40 foot long by 23 foot tall or larger sculpture. It would sit on a grassy knoll brooding like all huge monoliths do. Or maybe better in the center of a meteor crater, looking off into the final frontier. 

Visitors helpless, would wander round feeling small, lie down in the mirror polished orbits, or find deliverance in its embracing shadows as ghosts of Moai conjure Stonehenge makers in the restless pilgrim hearts. 

At such scale, Olduvai would be a titan fossil fragment to shine on all the days of future past......
Figure around $1M USD and donation of an appropriate site should suffice. But about as likely as the world shrinking/village thing.
@belartandstyle wow- especially coming from someone who's a master on  windows of the soul... now the bar just a lot higher :)

data.alt: 24x33 panel 3/4 thick Float Pla - thoskite | ello

body.data: This 24x33" panel of 3/4" thick Float Plate glass was the 1st of 4 architectural glass panels for a stair installation in 2005. About 250 lbs of glass was cut to size for it. Then diamond wet saws and drills were used to make the cutouts. Each panel was kiln formed/fire polished over graphite rods at 1,300 degrees Fahrenheit, annealed, and brought down to room temp in a computer controlled cooling ramp of 70 hours. More about design goals and installation in following posts- Panel Detail:

data.alt: Design Considerations/Goals- St - thoskite | ello

body.data: Design Considerations/Goals- Stair Project: architectural glass for stair is viewed from both sides & traveled through both going up and down the half-flight of cherry steps with oak risers. • Thick float plate glass shows a rich green tint on edge due to iron impurities in the glass. • The color of cherry stair treads and that type of glass would benefit from each other in terms of contrast just as wood and glass textures do when brought together. The stairs have a sculptural presence that the glass should respond to in kind. Further, the act of going up and down stairs brings to mind traversing musical scales and its written notation. • A thick, heavy glass would match the weight of the stair treads, but should take the geometric rigidity of the step repetition and mess with it, adding spatial counterpoint. • Subtle visual allusions to music could be used to connect to viewers' rhythm of movement as they pass between the panels. • This would need a fluid expression in 3D and kiln forming is ideal for that. Cutouts in the glass panels would increase the movement in the glass forming process to break the 2D plane much more than working a solid sheet. • Light refracting/bouncing off the repeating irregular glass surfaces complete a sense of movement within a frozen cascade of change. A few more shots and project specs in last post- 1st stair project post ................................................................. data.alt: hurricanes 8 takeaways high win - thoskite | ello

body.data: Been thru hurricanes before, but none like this. 8 takeaways on a high wind event (over 160 MPH): 1. Fingernails really do bleed if super motivated to hold onto something hard enough. 2. Trees can fly and sound like cannon when they snap in two just before takeoff. 3. After it sinks in that life & death's ruled by chaos, concentrating on patching windows with scraps of plywood and a screw gun can be done in an intensely focused manner. (see 1.) 4. Under severe storm conditions, extremely busy people don't have time to be terrified, but if they did at least their pants are already wet. Post storm: 5. Amid filth and rubble, bleeding fingernails get infected quickly in semitropical climates and rubbing alcohol seems to be the only surefire way to control it, unfortunately. 6. Climate deniers need to have the opportunity to 'shelter in place' at one of these events before doubling down on that. 7. People are hardwired to do the right thing when everything goes terribly wrong. No red state/blue state foolishness- just do whatever it takes to help each other survive. 8. When life's too easy, humans invent reasons to crap on each other. (corollary to 7.)

And this post was supposed to be about a simple game that people can enjoy as a little diversion from all the strident crap flying around about an election that should be bringing us together, not set us at each others' throats. Then last Sunday, while digging out what remains of our studio and tallying up the ruined equipment, my partner of over 40 yrs fell and fractured her spine. Finally got her to an orthopedic surgeon Tuesday and x-rayed, (hospital closed here still due to hurricane damage). It confirmed, she’s pretty much out of circulation for a while. Had a special back brace flown in yesterday and hope to get her using that a bit at a time over the next week. We've been in pretty deep shit before. And regardless of being someone who can tear up at all kinds of sentimental stuff, she's made of pure iron. Now, while it's being tested yet again- quitting isn't an option so don't even think about it... as usual. You find you have to bring your best game not because it's expected, rather just to keep up with her. But you also have to pick your battles. Yesterday's storm, last night's, today's and the tarped roof leaking steadily is like bailing out the ocean with a spoon. A new roof anywhere from 3 weeks to 3 months out. St. Johns insurance company never returning our calls let alone sending a check for even an initial, partial payment. And- best of all- FEMA saying we're ineligible for aid because, "...the damage to your property was not caused by the disaster" - (Hurricane Michael). Sure- why not? In the clearing stands a boxer... and carries the reminders... so I am leaving I am are leaving but the fighter will too... -to fight another god damned day.

data.alt: 5 cast acrylic columns time jaz - thoskite | ello

body.data: These 5 cast acrylic columns were made for a one time jazz performance collaboration at the New England Conservatory of Music in the '70s. "Carnival of Lost Souls" was composed and lead by Clyde Criner at keyboards. The sculpture ensemble was titled "5 for the Carnival" in an attempt to personify both the music and musicians making it. Lit from above with 5 stage lights, FX leveraged the fiber optic qualities of the columns. Transmitted light traveled from the top down to the bottom and back up each shaft in such a way as to make them glow from the bottom up as the lights were brought up and then down as each of the lights were reduced in sync with the music. So individual column's intensities visually varied similar to how pipes of a pipe organ each lend their voices to a flow of sound. All this was done on the fly, by hand, using the stage lighting levers for each column which with only 2 hands running things, still yielded a surprising number of possible combinations. Larger diameter/taller columns were used to respond to lower tones and high ones used the smaller thinner ones. Overall volume was reflected in the overall brightness with silence being completely dark up to crescendos floating in all 5000 watts of light. Primitive by today's FX show standards, it seemed pretty impressive at the time. However, the music was so incredible it just blew that room away. Later, the largest column was selected to show in a regional exhibition- juried by Jim Dine. The 5 were submitted to the show as a single work, but Dine decided that breaking up the work to show only 1 piece of it was somehow more appropriate. The 1st reaction to his decision was to opt out of the show. Unfortunately, being a hungry young 'artist', it seemed somehow acceptable to go along with Dine's infinite arrogance and the big column was shown alone. Of course, to this day that was a serious mistake. And karma of that is as follows- no one bought them as a set. Rather, 3 of them never sold and of the 2 that did, 1 was destroyed in a fire a few years later. The trio that's left, recently survived the hurricane without a scratch. They just got very wet which doesn't matter anymore than does a jackass jury of one's opinion about them & art. More shots and pearls of wisdom on art, music making, & existential stuff in the next couple of related posts... In the '70s, made a series of creatures 1st based on Dante's Inferno. Not content, they branched out, co-opting bits from the new field of Recombinant DNA, fossils, and lymnology. Add to that life drawing/anatomy study filtered thru haunting experiences in the operating room as a part-time scrub nurse handing knives and forks to surgeons performing lifesaving procedures on the one hand and horribly disfiguring, often pointless, radical cancer resections on the other.

data.alt: '70s, series creatures 1st base - thoskite | ello

body.data: Initially named Metatarsus Hominid from the human feet, these creatures seemed to come from either the very distant past or future or both. Got acquainted with metatarsals, (foot bones), when Clyde Criner broke one in my left foot during a basketball game in 7th or 8th grade. We were going up for the rebound and he came down on it. The coach thought it a ruse to get out of gym early so had to limp around school for the rest of the day and finally ended up at the family doctor who worked out of his house. Dr. Hempstead had a fluoroscope and turned the screen so the broken bone shown glowing eerily greenish yellow in real time. It was a "green stick" fracture which meant the bone broke splitting lengthwise with only part of the bone actually breaking and the rest bending to spring back after impact. Something older bones can't do. Clyde was a born musician and composer of deep, wide talent. Brahms was his favorite classical composer. With borrowed money made a collaborative performance work in Lucite sculpture to light on stage in sync with the Masters jazz recital of his "Carnival of Lost Souls" at the New England Conservatory of Music. Having at that point spent years steeped in Dante's Inferno, both figuratively and literally including in a corner of healthcare hell, Clyde's theme was one we both shared. In 2006, learned by accident Clyde died in his late 30s. The last conversation with him before we lost touch was when he visited our barn studio in Maine- just a few years before his death. We talked about art and music and then why he hadn't found his place in the big time jazz scene. He said the record guys told him his music wasn't "Black enough". Hearing Mozart always brings that conversation to mind because of a scene in Amadeus. Mozart's told one of his works is "1st rate", but there're just "...too many notes". Guess Clyde had come to say goodbye and talk of things undone. But, he didn't spell it out. Just parted with the shared feeling that all things are mercurial. Around the time we closed our Maine studio, unknown to us- an amazing musician and friend left this life. One thing's certain, his carnival of lost souls has just as many notes as he required, neither more nor less. Post 1 - Jazz recital Post 2 - In the field Post 4 - River run Clyde Criner Live: UMass Amherst 1980 -

data.alt: Bees laser engraving 12 3/4 pin - thoskite | ello

body.data: Bees is a laser engraving on 12 x 12 x 3/4 inch pine. The honey bees image sent to the laser is a lower res, 2 bit BMP with diffusion dither meant to give detail while leveraging the hardness variation in the softwood grain. The laser's set at a constant power, but vaporizes the softer areas more deeply. The resulting relief is reminiscent of fossil embedment and that long record of extinction. Bees have been in serious trouble for a while, but it's now becoming clear the entire insect ecosystem is collapsing from human impact. Such an event will likely put humans in line for the same sooner than later.

@ideflex yea the dithering does give it a needlepoint look. Works well for glass engraving where you get a chipping effect that really sparkles. Europe's been ahead of the US on the Roundup ban, but looks like there's more going on than just that.

data.alt: Turns human touch sensitive nan - thoskite | ello

body.data: Turns out human touch is sensitive down to the nano scale. Finger tips really do feel bumps the size of large molecules or in other words, down to 5 - one hundred thousandths of an inch. So here's "Touch", a hotshop cast, art glass sculpture about- you guessed it- touch. In 2006, molten glass at around 2000F was poured from a long handled, iron ladle into a greensand mold. It took 3 ladles to fill. After annealing down to room temp and a few years later, the glass was cut into 2 pieces on a diamond bandsaw after the roughed out shapes had been cold worked, smoothed, and battuto style engraved on the relief side of each piece. Battuto is an Italian term for a glass surface cut to resemble beaten metal. The glass shapes set up facing each other occupy a roughly 5 x 8 x 6 inch space.

Making these pieces was by and about touch, more or less like all sculpture. Unfortunately, most of us learn early we can only communicate with such objects visually, having deep scars left from the child abuse inherent in "do not touch" signs all around luscious things just begging to be handled. 

When you start to let the spectacular sensitivity of human hands sink in, the question arises- how much more are they actually understanding and communicating than we think? Even if much of it is subconscious, our hands feel things at a level of detail orders of magnitude greater than anything the naked eye takes in. 

For example- below are 2 Kirlian photographs of coronal discharge (auras) from women and men. Unknown to us, stuff like this is going on all the time. Yet, it's very possible our finger tips sense this phenomena in some way as well as other things we don't directly recognize. More reason  intimacy of touch is at the foundation of our being.

body.data: Back to 2D Art, "Electric Kool-Aid Acid Tess" is the latest from a 10 year old pelta tessellation that jumped the fence to become a Mech/game pattern then turned 2D Meme Mech which turned a page in PeltaPeeps history that started multiple threads, 3D, UV, and on... and on... So about this image- In the 60's some LSD called Monterrey Purple was attributed with starting the "psychedelic revolution" at the Monterrey Pop Festival. In high school, became acquainted with Purple Ocelot, an east coast flavor of same possibly. The onetime ride was intense including a listen to Inna Gadda Da Vida where sounds where forming shapes, colors as they came out of the stereo speakers. Later, on a fire escape, mountains across the valley were gently breathing in the afternoon sunlight and it became very clear it was time to leave a place that was neither gentle or kind. There's a Bach-like riff in the Iron Butterfly tune that's like those mountains and the agency they gave to push back by having the guts to walk away from what you're expected to do and do what you need to- come what may. Anyway- going to detail a maker trip thru design/character evolution (posted over a couple of months) Post 1: Electric Kool-Aid Acid Tess 4 fun (U R here) Post 2: Tess turns Mech Debut Post 3: PeltaPeeps & Mech Agree Post 4: Art needs to 3D More Post 5: Add some Camo to stay Alive Post 6: 3D print just for Kicks Post 7: Back to 3D Heaven Post 8: Bulk it up with some Plate Post 9: Out of Rhyme & Time @elloblog @ello @ellomakers @elloart @ellotextures @ellodesign @ellowrites #acid #LSD #gameart #games #pelta #tessellate #tessellation #gamesarttk #circles #2D #makers #characterdesign #meme #mech #3D #history #gamedesign #makers #geometry #geometricart #abstractart #abstract #boardgames #game #gamesarttk #ironbutterfly #music #synesthesia

data.alt: 2008, started messing symmetry  - thoskite | ello

body.data:
Around 2008, started messing with certain symmetry ideas in a vector program. That meant digital circles since they're the most symmetric geometric primitive. That lead to peltas- circles within circles like the ones you find in the windmills of your mind. Tessellation's also about symmetry. So, the design flowed toward exploring deconstruction of very simple forms, without breaking a few made-up as you go rules and then getting that to tessellate. One of the pattern variations started to appear reminiscent of '90s Mech stuff, but pretty much ended there. Or at least decided to just bide its time...

Because after a long time Making, now it's about focus 1st on orchestrating conditions that are ripe for something to emerge. Then when that does happen, start listening to what's been made. Sometimes you're greeted with a clear direction to continue and other times- complete silence to the point of not getting it at all. Not even knowing if what you're looking at is still in progress or completed- let alone where it may lead. But, Time resolves this in minutes, weeks or years. Just wait. Listen. Wait some more.

data.alt: 8 years Mech design clear neede - thoskite | ello

body.data: 8 years later, the Mech design made it clear it needed pilots and a reason to Mech around. At that time, PeltaPeeps were hanging out as another pelta doodle when the Magic Table turned them into game stars. It was Thanksgiving and the table had left another game design to be found. It took a few weeks to put it all together. The PeltaPeeps were being worked into the new game piece design and an old tessellating pattern looking like fish scales was introduced into the mix. That's when they took a look at the dusty Mech tessellation and it was love at 1st byte. (Below some PetaPeeps clowning around on the game pieces)-

With the Magic table dropping ongoing backstory hints, things started gathering steam and tapped additional designs some of which were made several decades earlier. Also, turns out memes can be weaponized and Mechs are naturals to be fitted with meme systems, thus MemeMechs. This lead to a bit of analog game art in the form a 12x12 inch UV print on a Baltic birch panel with a UV printed tessellated frame. UV printing is a type of inkjet printing on steroids. The acrylic ink is instantaneously cured by intense UV light moving with the printhead. The moment ink hits the surface being printed it's cured and adhered. Not only can UV prints handle printing on and stick to a wide range of surfaces such as wood, metal, glass and so on, but they can also print on objects of various thickness and even round shapes. And these printers extend printing to relief, full color images on materials of any color by extending CMYK to add printing white as well as clear varnish in multi-layer. Think a full color print on a clear drinking glass with a Braille caption below it in relief. So naughty tactile ink ridges on analog game pieces that finger tips can OD stroking is just the beginning!

data.alt: story lines developed, art star - thoskite | ello

body.data:
As story lines developed, the art started to lag behind. The PeltaPeeps were also getting bored w/ 2D so a simple design extrusion was performed and UV printed on 12x12 inch maple plywood. This quickly faded into "not enough", but maybe going in the right direction. 

Here's another maker process at work. Digital design can benefit from transition from narrative to image and then into the analog world as a print just as analog design can in reverse. Often something tangible is needed now and then. Either way, touchable vs untouchable is huge because ideas feed off the new perspective gained. Meaning comes from how something is delivered to the mind and that path affects what it turns out to be.

FE1: Color from a screen (RGB=white light) is additive and projected at the eye. Color from a surface (RYB=black) is subtractive and seen only as reflected light. The hues may appear basically the same, but the experience is not. There's more life in reflected color because light and environment constantly change. FE2: Knowing the shape on a screen or in a picture that represents a sphere is entirely different than touching a sphere. Merely seeing leaves its size uncertain. Close your eyes while holding the sphere for even more information. What's left is- the deepest understanding of form doesn't even need sight. These simple differences are anything but simple. Our subconscious minds are constantly aware of 3D in terms of our body parts, position in space, shape of objects and space around us, as well as what subtle or sudden changes are going on to all of that, all the time. An image on the wall or on screen work on your mind very differently and get processed as such. At the least, shifting them from one state to the other is an excellent tool to increase dialog with whatever the hell's being made. data.alt: Importing extrusion 3D program  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Importing the extrusion into a 3D program was an interesting, if backwards way to explore the shapes at play. And it did conjure new form which also triggered how the camouflage on war ships from WWI deconstructed the silhouette/shape of really large objects. Applied to MemeMechs and their pilot PeltaPeeps this gives an interesting highwayman/Zorroesque mask vibe- kinda sinister with a smirk thing going on the side.

So here's another creative process point/problem to leverage or at least deal with. Should you foster a creative- go wherever multiple mediums lead? Or is it better to stick to making the core design more approachable? To illustrate- there's a good case to be made that games that use familiar narratives are more welcoming/inclusive. Game mechanics can be set in a Viking, space opera, or any number of other archetype narratives- all of which resonate with a broad range of players. So why go to the trouble of making a new narrative that may in fact raise the affective barrier to learning/playing a new game? 2 reasons come to mind. 1st, originality has value, especially for the jaded. 2nd, from a maker's POV, if switching gears from digital to analog and back increases cross-fertilization in design dev, the same can be said for switching back and forth from visual design to storytelling. Writing has more in common with digital visual design than it does analog in terms of its ability to shrug off real world constraints. Also, while all of this really belongs in the territory of the mind, imagery and narrative have sufficiently different languages that together give rise to a wider spectrum of expression. Then adding animation and sound provides the 4th dimension via video. And so on...

data.alt: growing impatience part analog  - thoskite | ello

body.data:
Meanwhile, there was growing impatience on everyone's part to get back into the analog world. Time to 3D print a MemeMech, 1st as a small scale test and then a larger size of 7x6x1 inches which is big by 3D printer standards. This also was an opportunity to see what the equipment/process could and couldn't do. 

Another process aspect of making is about folding the continuing acquisition of new skills into building on old ones. But it's more than that... it involves how to learn on the fly while pushing the envelope on what new skills/equipment/software is met with. Here, expediency becomes part of the mother of invention. Most truly valuable skills and/or processes are difficult to master and have steep learning curves. Those curves are painful, stopping or slowing things down at critical times when there's a kind of rhythm that must be maintained. So looking to add new technique needs to be targeted at the particular work going on and it's here that just enough to get what's needed is key. In other words, mastery of something new isn't the goal. Just get what counts for that moment and building skill will take care of itself as it becomes an ongoing requirement. Of course the best part is that discovery/exploring new process/skills directly impacts the finished work, enhancing it.

But, pushing the envelope comes 1st because it's impossible to know the possible without establishing failure boundaries. FE: If the manual says support structure is required for overhangs in a 3D print- print withOUT the support structure. Fail. Look closely at how that happened and what jumps out at you is- it's partly a gravity thing. OK, try printing without it again, but change the print mode to deposit less material per printhead pass. That's done by setting the printer to a higher resolution. Still Fail, but not nearly as much. Take-aways from actually seeing what happens rather than taking the manual's word for it is huge. The printhead CAN print overhangs if they're connected or contiguous and the scale is right for the material to cool fast enough not to deform. It still can NOT print in thin air (completely unconnected to the last pass). There'll come a time when you need to know exactly where that difference is to create a special effect or figure time savings vs quality or some other thing not even on the horizon right now.

Once the large model was printed, it was clear it needed a UV print job applied to it. This 2 process, UV and 3D printing, together look to have serious possibilities especially if worked out in advance instead of just winging it. 

Too much is never enough...

data.alt: 3D print cycle yielded exciting - thoskite | ello

body.data:
After the 3D print cycle yielded exciting, albeit mixed results, now need to build new MemeMechs from scratch in true 3D. This called for basing the effort directly on the old original 2D vector tessellation's criteria. That took going back to geometric primitives to make the translation genuine. Circles within circles turned into cylinders within spheres and so on... 

Well, 3D shapes exploded into all kinds of variations and file sizes got huge quick which triggered upgrading to a desktop beast. Something fast sporting big-assed, solid-state drives to handle full 3D rendering, animation, movies, Unity platform development stuff, and/or calculating π to the end of time. Building a computer from scratch is the best way to get some of that. 

But to save time better used to reanimate an army of the dead with abby-normal brains, started with an off-the-shelf MSI heavy duty graphics machine and transplanted that into a tower box which allowed upgrade to CPU liquid cooling. Then add: a pinch of salt, fan controller, extra fans, DVD burner, and still have room for future hardware. Mix well then wait for a lightning storm and voila...

data.alt: Magic providing game stuff, pre - thoskite | ello

body.data: Recently the Magic table's been providing more game stuff, much of which is pretty hazy. There's notions of a Unity play space/environment where you take a MemeMech for a spin.
It could be a kind of Surrealist Hall of Fame where burning giraffes run free and Elephants of Celebes watch Holy Mackerel fly by in the sky. Or poke around in the Garden of Earthly Delights.

But, with leaving what's left from the hurricane behind by moving to Rocket City and building a new studio along with leasing 2000 sf at Lowe Mill to open an experimental art/game space- bandwidth to pick up Unity and Blender skills has moved to the street of dreams for now. 

The good news is PeltaPeeps debuted at the 2018 US Mensa Mind Games and got plenty of positive response. However, getting closer to the right combination of process and materials to mass produce it at a affordable price is tougher than it should be. Meanwhile- 2 other games starring PeltaPeeps are coming along. PeltaWorld One (about getting gamed by climate change), is mostly baked and now needs extensive game test while game 3, PeltaDrome, is still thrashing out game mechanics. Need to conjure a doppelganger or 3 to keep things rolling. That said, finally a closing word about process - 

Ego can be mistaken for the focus it takes to refuse to dilute the pursuit of making. But in fact, ego stands between making and outcome. When it's removed the process becomes clear and the outcome secondary. The resulting image, object, written word, or whatever is shown to have its own arc. When the result's good or even great, what bystanders see is easily misunderstood as a triumph of the maker which it's not, anymore than honey is a triumph of the bee. And it's the last place to look for inspiration. What's made has its life of minutes or millennia to inspire. 

That's it.

Oh- and don't go where the huskies go... @pokalupsis very happy to hear it. was concerned it was veering between tedium and rambling. 

Your point about varying tool timeframes being builtin is spot on. had thought of media in that way before, but not the tools themselves. Your approach seems more accurate. FE- always thought of glass being a medium that requires a long timeframe, but that really isn't the case unless you're talking about kiln work or certain kinds of cold working. Hand or laser engraving glass produce immediate results and a buzz of instant gratification when stuff is clicking. It's not the media, it's the tool at hand.

@pokalupsis been thinking about the difficulty of taking the ego out of the process. It's easy to say be like the Zen archer and aim without aiming, but how the hell is that done? Seems it comes down to- not trying to impose, but instead go with what's already happening. Think of it as if there are no beginnings just a stream of unmade things going by that can be realized. 

Guess this sounds like more Zen bullshit, but, if you buy into it- framing it this way does take the pressure off of the "now I must be creative" urge. That pressure is surely from ego. 

Then turn inward toward what's taking place with the thing being made by listening to it. What is it saying about where to go next? Again, the pressure of what do I do next, (ego), is removed by letting the object take over and the process flows from and follows that.

It does work, but ya gotta drink the KoolAid. Fun fact- apparently Jim Jones used cyanide in FlavorAid not KoolAid, but KoolAid sounds, well, cooler so why mess with the meme.

@pokalupsis skill used to be a big hangup (ego again) for moi. FE: Gauguin’s prints are lousy technically from a printmaker's POV because they're uneditionable. (actually that may not be entirely true) So maybe skill isn't critical if the result works.

@pokalupsis agree on having as high as possible standards. Yet offsetting that is the thing about there being no perfection without imperfection. That dichotomy appears to be at the heart of the best work by being held within it.

data.alt: Started traditional glass engra - thoskite | ello

body.data: Started doing traditional glass engraving in the late '70s. Pictures show the 2nd home built engraver in action in a little shed on Cape Cod. Termed glass lathes, they aren't at all like wood or metal lathes. Had a metal guy cut in half a steel girder rising from the cast iron base of an junked vertical belt sander. Then he welded a plate to it where we set up a special arbor to run stone wheels. All that iron killed any possibility of vibration- the mortal enemy of glass cutting. Couldn't find real stone wheels for glass work anywhere, but the library yielded info on contacting 3M to have some abrasive ceramic wheels specially made for glass work. It took months to get to the right person and get the right formula of hardness and grit size, but finally ordered some 12" and 6" wheels which arrived about 2 months later. The rest was trial and mostly error, although it seemed at the time the most fun you can have with your pants on. Still is. @udiophile @dabi thank you- discovering how to do something on your own beats the hell out of art school or any other kind. Of course, you may end up doing it all wrong. FE: properly trained European engravers will scoff at the complete travesty going on in these pics. The glass is being engraved from the WRONG side of the wheel which means the wheel is rotating in the WRONG direction. So that makes the water drip also in the wrong spot not to mention it's supported by a coat hanger. The lighting is bad and a bread pan??? and so on and on...

But if what comes out is OK- screw it!

Whether stone, diamond, or copper- the wheel's profile determines various shapes or styles of line engraving glass just like a painter's selection of brush on canvas. Stone wheels are more versatile than diamond because the maker can shape them into custom versions of 3 basic profiles. This video by Corning Museum of Glass, shows different wheel profiles doing their stuff. But, the narrator got it wrong- the star glass cut isn't "brilliant cut". In the video, it looks shiny because it's still wet from being cut. When dry, it'll appear frosted. It is NOT brilliant cut until it's polished to clear. Here's the difference-

data.alt: stone, diamond, copper- profile - thoskite | ello

body.data: The eye in the fish design* above is brilliant cut as are some bubble shapes. The rest is intaglio cut. A separate wheel does the polishing. It's made of poplar wood to match the stone wheel. A slurry of water and cerium oxide brushed on the wheel brings the cut up to an optical (clear) polish. As opposed to diamond wheels, stone ones leave a satiny surface that's polished in just one step.  But, it needs to be done carefully because the cut can suddenly overheat- result: work shatters.

*Fish Bones was done 40 years ago after looking at a lot of pelio carp fossils. Used to frame many of these engravings in Tiffany style leaded glass then. Here a blue/burgundy, English opalescent, "mottle" glass was used round the cut glass work. data.alt: Germany 15 years scored 2 Spatz - thoskite | ello

body.data:
In Germany 15 years ago, scored 2 Spatzier glass lathes & a crateful of very special old stone wheels. The small lathe's meant for engraving & the old big 1 for glass cutting (brilliant cutting & large panels).  But once these babies get set up in a studio- it's what the hell they want to do. 

Both machines got thru the hurricane without a scratch and are busting to get running again at Lowe Mill. Their impatience can't be overstated- to hear cold hard glass start to sing at wheel's touch- arcs, stars, and moonlight fingers follow sleeping rhythms like Bach toccatas scattering notes into sunbeams sparkling off each fresh new facet... or whatever. Pics below are from 2009 in a studio outside of Seattle.

Above- one of the last small Spatzier glass engravers- built in 2004. Diamond spindles are in the wood rack behind with a tiny stone wheel mounted on engraver. There's a piece of orange Flash glass used for test engraving leaning against the machine. Below- large Spatzier glass cutter made early 1900's or older? The old stone wheels in the lower rack are up to 24" dia. and 2" thick. Larger wheels run at slower speeds than small ones so the flat belt, step pulleys on both machines are a 18th century way to change shaft speeds for differing wheel sizes.

data.alt: 5 reasons wheel engraving door  - thoskite | ello

body.data: 5 reasons wheel engraving door panels or any large glass is nuts. ONE: Stationary glass lathes require the glass to move when cutting designs. TWO THREE and FOUR: Plus glass weighs about the same as granite per cubic foot which means not only does a large glass engraving have to be setup to swing freely over the wheel in all directions, it also must have a substantial counter weight to make it at all manageable and it can NOT interfere with the free movement. FIVE: One mistake either- cutting the design or polishing the cuts or hand grinding or trimming the panel afterward and kiss what could easily be weeks of work goodbye. Or just call it "practice" if you've already lost your marbles. So- got an old roller barn door rail and wheel carriage and bolted it to a 14' 2x10 nailed to 2 posts in the Barn studio in Maine in the '80s. From a Volvo car wreck, took a steering column that had a universal joint on each end of it and connected 1 end to the overhead wheels and the other end to an eye bolt in the center of an oak balance beam. The universal joints gave decent freedom of movement, but dampened a pendulum effect. On one end of the beam, glass panels were hung and the other end took weights added on to offset the glass.

Crude, but effective once you have painfully learnt all the secret handshakes. data.alt: Victorian cut glass door panels - thoskite | ello

body.data:
Victorian cut glass door panels were wheel engraved, polished to brilliant cut, and then hand ground to produce a frosted background. After completing the brilliant cutwork- hand grinding is done by making a slurry of fine sand or carbide grit and water. Pour it on a thick plate glass at least 1.5 times the width and twice the length of the panel to be frosted. The engraved glass is placed cut side down and moved by hand in a figure 8 pattern over the plate glass thus only grinding the flat surfaces and leaving the engraved/polished depressions clear. Grinding stops a soon as the flats are evenly frosted.  

Below is an oak door with oval light that took a panel cut with 42 stars made up of 168 miter wheel cuts each of which was then polished along with the round wheel cut which runs the entire perimeter of the 50x24" panel. All cutting is done freehand making long cuts like the perimeter one by far the most difficult. So it's best to do them 1st as a slip won't trash quite as much work. Large panel cutting requires focus, steady hands, and some upper body strength.
Percy (glass etching to the left of door) just had to get in the shot. What a ham.

After cutting/polishing, the panel was hand ground to frost the background, washed off and installed in the door. To meet building code, the brilliant cutting was done on 2 layer, laminated safety glaze- a type of float plate glass. This was cut with stone and diamond wheels in a variety of coarse to very fine grits. Then kiln formed and fire polished in a single firing. The forming stretches the cut shapes, leaving them intact while the rougher surfaces resist the fire polish and the smooth ones turn clear. All provide a spectrum of texture to bounce around light passing thru.

data.alt: cut stone diamond wheels variet - thoskite | ello

body.data: Fire polishing is a faster way to polish wheel engraving. At room temp, glass isn't a solid, but more like a very stiff liquid. In a glass kiln, it gets softer and more runny as it gets hotter. At around 1500F, it's like syrup. Also, glass is very bad at transferring heat so the surface gets much hotter than the center and here's where fire polishing can be done without losing the engraving. Between 900 and 1150F a rapid temp rise can make the surface gloss without it getting hot enough to deform. Fire polishing can save a tremendous amount of time, only sacrificing a small loss in the crispness of the cuts.

Turning Tide Too is a 14x7x6" sculpture made from 3/4" heavy plate glass. Engraving wheels have one of 2 modes of expression. One is to carve the surface out to its final form leaving no sign of the tools involved. Cameo carving, providing a specific person's portrait in relief, is an example. 

The other way is to use the vocabulary of shapes that flow from the cutting wheels themselves to form  each word in a kind of glass cutting language speaking both of how it came to be and what it's become . This piece is from a series that listens to the wheels speak of things beyond the maker.

data.alt: Glass making 5000 years Egypt M - thoskite | ello

body.data: Glass making goes back at least 5000 years to Egypt and Mesopotamia and glass engraving has always been part of that. By 500 BC engraving gemstones was common and glass, considered just as precious, was a natural for the same techniques.
But glass engraving really took off in the Roman Empire at Alexandria around the 1st century AD.

Through glass, sometimes darkly, can be seen everything known and unknown. It's the only medium that, no matter where it is- draws its surroundings directly into it. Light, shadow, color, even movement are all at play within a glass object as it reflects some and lets others pass within. It can persist 1000s of years and then shatter in an instant- stress its enemy and luck its friend. 

In a chaotic universe, it's so at home that its very structure is neither solid nor liquid, but both.
