data.alt: diamond cut 3 circles 3/4 thick - thoskite | ello

body.data:
A diamond saw was used to cut out 3 circles from 3/4" thick glass for fusing together. The stack consisted of a solid top and bottom disk with a ring sandwiched in between them. Prior to fusing, the inside of the ring and inward surfaces of the disks were wheel engraved- partly in a style called "notching".  Fusing temp was limited to around 1200F resulting in more of a 'tack' fuse (mechanical join) rather than full merging of the parts. A higher temp would have badly eroded the engraved shapes now trapped within. 

Fine cuts were made to let internal pressure escape from the center space during firing. It worked- allowing the top surface to slump to a concave shape. 

This is the last post on Traditional Glass Engraving series (and monkeys might fly out of...).

data.alt: farthest wheel engraving glass  - thoskite | ello

body.data:
What's farthest away from wheel engraving glass you can get? Laser engraving it. So get a 100 watt laser-
> Then engrave mirror instead of plate glass. 
> Then find out if it's possible to engrave the silvered backside of the mirror because online says it can't be done. 
> Then paint the resulting stencil where the laser vaporized the backing and copper and silvering and actually engraved the damned glass all in one pass. 

And you get stuff like: Bees Knees- (above) laser engraved and painted mirror, 36x12" unframed.

Sure as hell isn't traditional glass engraving... but it's kinda smokin'...

data.alt: wood version design laser inter - thoskite | ello

body.data:
@abstractcolorism thanks. there is pretty good detail up close. 

no- the can't laser mirror thing is internet misinformation. you can laser engrave mirror either the glass side or the back without flashback. 

the laser has to be focused to deliver a beam spot powerful enough to vaporize the substrate. the lens that does the final focus of the beam coming out of the gantry head has a focal length like any camera lens. only material within the focused beam will be subjected to enough power to do anything. reflected, unfocused laser beams could damage vision possibly, but are otherwise not going to do much.

in fact, when laser cutting- most lasers have the ability to swap out lenses of different focal lengths depending on the thickness of the material to be cut.

@abstractcolorism interesting- wonder what got damaged? there's a special coating on the lens that might get comprised. my experience is with 100 and 150 watt glass tube lasers and engraved maybe 150 mirror backs with no drop in power.  only engraved a few mirror on the glass front as the effect gets reflected in the mirror and isn't particularly interesting.

do you recall what wattage that laser was?

@abstractcolorism being an amorphous solid, glass may not have the same reflectivity that a metal does. guessing that the glass also chips under laser bombardment so quickly it negates most if not all reflectivity of the silvering when engraving the backside of mirror. of course, this is all wildass conjecture.

@photostatguy bet you do the same thing with cameras- it's the only way to find out the limits of the equipment you're working with. 

plus it's fun to push things

data.alt: Bees Knees buzz laser engraved  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Bees Knees got a buzz from the laser engraved mirror thing so much they decided why not a glass vase next? They've got a thing for flowers apparently. Meanwhile, as most of us would, glass violently reacts to anything trying to vaporized it. When the laser pulse hits the glass surface the sudden, extreme heat causes an instant fracture resulting in a chip flying off. The effect is similar to diamond point, stipple engraved glass.  So to jazz things up a bit, the engraving image was tweaked to produce larger chips as were laser settings for power/speed. This gives the engraved glass more sparkle.

What's next: if properly introduced- looks like laser and wheel engraving could make beautiful music together because too much is never enough... data.alt: 36 - 2 fused glass cubes 4 sets - thoskite | ello

body.data:
Made 36 - 2" fused glass cubes in 4 sets of 9. After multiple fusing, cutting, refusing, and recutting- the real painstaking process began. Based on the amount of wet grinding, finishing, and polishing 6 sides of each cube, it took between about 12 and 18 hours per piece. In the over 500 hours spent (not counting kiln work), focus and concentration were key. 

During work on the last set, 3 of the pieces took advantage of momentary lapses in attention to think outside the cube by flying across the room. After assessing the damage, they made it clear they wanted to be hella pyramidal or polygonal or any goddamn thing, but NOT a cube! 

So after all the rest were done, the troublemakers got their wish even though they left the last cube set of 9 short by 3.

Moral: There's no " i " in 9 Cube Set, but there is in Iconoclast. data.alt: WTF poem video written years li - thoskite | ello

body.data:
WTF is this? Well it's a poem in a video or whatever, written a few years ago listening to 5 clocks in our house strike the hours day in and day out, over many years in all the places we've lived. Clocks are the heart beat of the homes they inhabit, but only if they're hand wound ones that ring out the hour while making a steady tick... tock. The older they are the better.

The clocks were made in New England, Scotland, London, and Germany. Two of them are tall case clocks- a rare jeweler's regulator and a drumhead grandfather clock. The others are a mantle clock passed down in the family, a wall regulator, and a brass ship's clock. They range in age from 15 to 190 years old. Four of the five agreed to run a little fast or slow so half the time they all can ring a solo account of the hour. The 5th clock strikes the exact time. That's the youngest one- a German wall regulator with laser cut brass works. Three of the others have handmade works. None of them use electricity. They all chime, some loud, others softly. The jeweler's regulator has a long tubular bell whose haunting sound puts the rest to shame. Life ebbs and flows around these clocks from one weekly winding to the next.

On the same day every week, more or less, the winder goes from one time piece to the other looking into the face of each as he winds it. Thoughts of the times they have clocked linger on those who have come and gone- ghosts whose hands wound and then adjusted their hands. In the Spring and Fall, the clocks usually need more adjustment as change of season can make them run a little fast or slow as they mark the passing years.

Now, four of the five have stopped. Only the ship's clock keeps time. The hurricane stopped the others. Two of them- the Scottish drumhead and the mantle clock had water pouring through them during the storm when part of the roof was torn off, but both kept running somehow for a couple of days until salt stopped their works. The others all succumbed to the damp in a week or two. But, the ship's clock, built for the hostile environment of the sea, did what it was supposed to.     
 
Someday the others will be restored and run again or not. It's just a matter of time.

The video is of the mantle clock stuck at quarter past 12. It's sitting on top of a TV cabinet while the usual mayhem goes on, patiently waiting to tick tock once more 604,800 seconds each week- 

31.5 million a year, 

and 2.5 billion a lifetime.

...they say-  make every second count
Below- Scottish Drumhead before the storm.

data.alt: England church Cumberland Maine - thoskite | ello

body.data: Made in the 80's for a New England church in Cumberland Maine, this leaded glass window was for a congregation wanting something plain, but spiritual, that would let in the light and Fall colors. They already had the window framed. Recall it as over 6 feet tall and maybe 3 wide. After approving a design sketch and materials, it was made in 2 sections- a bottom and top with a steel separator between, plus 2 steel saddle bars for strength. The glass used was a bit of French antique (hand blown) glass, some iridescent streaky opal, glue-chipped clear, float plate clear 1/8" thick for most of the background, and 1/2" for around 200 hand ground and polished bevels. The bevels were roughed out on a coarse diamond, 2" wide wheel, smoothed on a fine diamond wheel , then a stone wheel , and finally polished on a big felt wheel. Some of the 1/8" clear was wheel engraved with stars and other shapes floating thru the design. The overall effect was about something the patrons could relate to, but not really made from that point of view. Instead, it came from this-

Having spent a lot of time learning about 1st one religion then several others- stopped when none worked enough to buy into. Then found a life partner whose childhood religion was different and painfully navigated, but never resolved, family disapproval from both sides.  So, there's a bit of irony accepting any commission of an ecclesiastical nature. 

But, Life was coming pretty unglued when this came along. Making the window was the only thing going that was good. Guess, making can be sort of a religion as good as any. Working the window became about what's above and beyond all the banal everyday bullshit. It was refuge rising in unstoppable twisting flashes wound around and around lifting up and up higher lighter singing infinite symmetries spinning ageless in thinnest air.

Yea, not much bible there. As it turned out though, the flock seemed pretty happy with it. No need for them to know how the sausage is made, thank dog. data.alt: SnowMoon Winter keeping house b - thoskite | ello

body.data: SnowMoon was made in Winter when keeping an old house and barn studio in Maine warm enough to live in, let alone work, was the kind of fun that gets old fast. Although it had its moments like watching the ice melt in the toilet bowl by peeing on it. Or learning all about how hot water pipes always freeze before cold water ones and how not to set the house on fire when soldering burst copper plumbing with a torch in walls stuffed with 100 year old newspapers that previous generations used for insulation in a futile attempt to keep from turning blue. But, if stain glass for all those medieval cathedrals could be done in worse conditions, who can bitch as long as you've got gloves with the finger tips cutoff and not a lot of sense?

A snow moon is the 2nd full moon of the winter which is about when this was finished. It was a, "carte blanche", commission for 2 doors in a cabinet. That's the best kind of work for hire and always gets the most put into it because you're free to follow things as they happen rather than stick to the melody.

So, after the drawing was approved, the different glasses were cut to fit the lead pattern.  2 single convex lens were wheel engraved along with various pieces of clear plate glass- some of which were brilliant cut and hand ground as well. Next, over 20 pieces of thick plate were ground to a bevel and polished. Last, some of the glue chip glass was acid etched to create a more subtle texture in contrast to the plain glue chip used. Finally, the panels were leaded in the Tiffany style of wrapping each piece's edges in copper foil, soldering them all together, putting a copper patina on the solder leading, and cleaning the chemicals off the finished panels.

The part harder than staying warm- not using technique for its own sake. That's because of glass' inherent beauty. Restraint's the maker's problem with glass and always has been. Update: the fool that made this post left out that French ruby and dark amber glasses were also used in small amounts. In 2006, Blind Joy, a hotshop cast glass piece from a green sand mold, joined our space/time. Made clear who it was, immediately having its way with any light around and as seasons flicker by. 

There're two faces to Blind Joy.
One facing the future and the other the past like the Roman god of beginnings/endings and time/change.
But, Blind Joy is forever in between- only in the present.

10" x 6" & 2" thick, now Untitled, (formerly the cast glass sculpture known as Transmarginal Inhibition), was made 13 yrs ago. Glass sheet in primary colors was cut into squares and then notched with slots using a diamond saw. The slots stop halfway thru each square so 2 squares slide together at right angles in egg crate fashion.  This allowed them to stand on edge, supporting each other.

data.alt: 10 6 2 thick, Untitled, cast gl - thoskite | ello

body.data:
Then 2 glass sets, a yellow egg crated with a blue and a yellow egg crated with a red, were set in a green sand mold along with some lamp worked, thin black glass rod and 2 graphite cylinders to create voids. Molten clear glass, (Spruce Pine Batch), at a little less than 2000F was poured over them. The egg crated sheets exploded from heat shock- shattering as they instantly melted into the flow of the clear glass pour. Graphite cylinders were removed when the glass dropped to around 1200F. Afterwards, the piece was put in an annealing kiln to slowly cool to room temp over the next few days. The glass block was then rough cut on a diamond wet saw and the back partially ground flat on a diamond lap.

Behavioral eggheads have identified 3 reactions that animals choose from when confronted by the extreme- fight, flight, or freeze. Transmarginal Inhibition, a term for the last of the three options, is in its making and result- a literal expression of frozen turmoil.

data.alt: French flash glass engraving le - thoskite | ello

body.data: Started making these in the '80s when there was a lot of "sun catcher" crap around. So it was hard to take a small format seriously. Yet wheel engraving is a very intimate technique especially when you just sit down and start without a drawing or often without even an idea. It's about letting the shapes flow from the wheel- 1st one then another and another and then change wheels and new shapes responding to what's there back and forth. More wheel changes and stop and start a new one long before you're done with the one on hand. then start a 3rd, 4th, and stop. Go back to an engraving left off on days or months ago- only changing from one piece to the next if the flow slows down or one gets stuck or needs a breather. Used to listen and watch a jazz musician friend improvise endlessly on the piano, each note or chord following another in riffs. There's a feeling like that. The glass knows it and starts singing Recent video, (below), using diamond spindles on 2 color and color on clear, French flash glass off-cuts. Off-cuts are scrap. The best stuff always happens on them because of the freedom from it 'counting'. https://vimeo.com/351825195?embedded=true&source=vimeo_logo&owner=92241895

data.alt: circles: 24 glass ceiling lamp  - thoskite | ello

body.data:
More circles: this 24" glass ceiling lamp shade was hung in '07 for the crime of being functional art. It was cut out, fused, kiln formed (2nd firing), and drilled for wire cables. Special opalescent glasses were stacked with pieces of float plate (window) glass and opalescent stringer (very thin glass rod). The opal glasses and stringer are special because they have the same Coefficient of Expansion (COE) as plate glass. 

COE is a measure of how much a glass shrinks as it cools to room temp. Glasses that have a difference of more than 2 or 3 COE are not compatible. Most art glasses have COEs of 90 or higher while most commercial glass such as  bottle or window glass have COEs well below 90. They will still fuse together when fired, but shatter when they cool or break days/weeks/years later depending on the amount of stress trapped inside- just like people.

The layup for the 1st firing was a bottom layer of 28" diameter by 1/8" thick, clear plate glass and then a same size layer of compatible warm grey opal followed by several layers of plate glass strips and arcs cut from 1/8" thick sheet using an ordinary glass cutter. Different colors of opal stringer were added last. Fusing was done to maintain a relief surface as was the later kiln forming when the glass was re-fired to slump over a bowl shaped, stainless steel form. There was no design drawn up to start with. Rather glass was cut, laid out, changed, recut, and changed again- watching for how the shapes interacted and, based on similar projects, estimating what that would translate into once fired. The upside of work done like this is- it goes wherever it leads. Downside is- it's wonderfully inefficient in terms of materials and time. But, the extra offcuts can be used to puzzle new designs while the additional time spent incubates whole new directions to pursue. So there is no downside. data.alt: Island Girl - fused/cold-worked - thoskite | ello

body.data: Island Girl - a fused/cold-worked Art glass panel, size: 26"x21"x5/8". It was made from a roughly 70 piece buildup of 5 layers of colored and opal art glass w/ clear strips of float plate glass on top to create a rich texture- both physical and optical.

The top and bottom irregular edges are left as they came out of the kiln. The smooth hourglass profile of the sides was done by freehand cutting the finished panel on a wet diamond bandsaw. After the cuts were made the sides were hand smoothed with fine grit diamond pads/files and water.

Often these things start by drawing with a glass cutter on glass instead of a pencil on paper. Then there's a nice shape and then another in response to the 1st and so on. This one did start that way. But early on it knew it was island girl so it finished itself. data.alt: people talk leaded glass window - thoskite | ello

body.data: When people talk about leaded glass windows with colorful glass in them as stained glass, they got it wrong. No painting that's been fired to fuse to the glass means leaded glass - NOT STAINED. Whew! -better now.

The two images above are of a truly exceptional stained glass panel made in the 16th Century- possibly around 1542. It's likely the bottom section of a much larger window and may identify the patron of the window- a common practice then. But now, who gives a tinker's damn if he was the Duke of Earl? The museum quality of this work comes from the exceptional brushwork in the extensive painting and staining throughout. There are also rare pieces of ruby flash glass that have been worked to partially remove the red flashed layer, then painted and silver stained in multiple firings. The unsurpassed workmanship here shows complete mastery of the stain glass Art in mid Renaissance Europe. Compare this to the example below from possibly 25 years earlier-

Restoring the Die Stat Bad panel involved carefully tracing the way the leads run, disassembling the panel, cleaning the old putty off each piece, and reassembling it with new lead "came" that matches as closely as possible, the original in style, size, and weight. Lead came oxidizes (rusts) very slowly eventually becoming brittle, weak, and powdery. A stain glass window will need to be releaded every 100 to 200 years depending on the conditions it's subjected to. So this panel was likely rebuilt at least 2 times before. There also were a couple of broken pieces of glass that needed to be ground to accept new leads at the break- a traditional restoration method to keep a panel original.

Leading is done by stretching the came to be cut- then with a special knife, trimmed and fitted to each individual glass piece. The came is held in place with horseshoe nails as another piece is fit and more nails and more fitting and so on until the panel is whole. Next, all the lead joints are soldered together, the panel carefully turned over, and the other side soldered. Last, glazing putty is made from whiting, raw linseed oil, and lamp black. Putty is gently worked into the lead came- filling and joining the glass to the lead to make the panel stiff once it sets over several days or more.

100 to 200 years from now, someone else may be releading it again. Handling and restoring something like this is bigger than you are. It remains while the restorer doesn’t. there's 2 kinds of traditional fired painting on the glass- the black or brown matte are used for figures and patterns and is more like a ceramic glaze that fuses as a layer on top of the glass- blocking light. The other is yellow that comes from a sliver solution that at high temp melts and is absorbed into the glass surface- staining it yellow. Light can pass thru the stained areas.

data.alt: started exploring push thicknes - thoskite | ello

body.data: This started as exploring how far you could push different thicknesses in a partial fuse of glass. It later became a way to make a series called- sea people. The glass is an arrangement of strips of thin window glass (1/8”) and thick blocks of heavy plate (3/4”).

It’s not supposed to work because the arrangement has thick and thin. The cooling process immediately starts to create stress at these junctions because the thicker glass cools much slower than the thin strips. And fused glass shapes don’t like sharp inside angles (≤ 90°). However, if you tweak the cooling cycle and slow it way down- you can get away with murder. Should’ve been- “What’s Better than Seeing a Hopper Painting? Sitting on One.” “Then a modern instinct kicked in: I set my phone’s photo timer and snapped a few pictures of myself posed as the painting’s sitter. As I prepared to post the winner to Instagram, my own wave of ambivalence washed over. In that moment, I was spending more energy capturing the perfect shot than experiencing the place I’d traveled to see. Alienation, indeed.” At best, seems more about separating the object from itself by imbuing it with all the deep meaning that art criticism can shovel. The social media/internet tune does the same with people self indulging in multiple personas turned evermore inward. At worst, this is grossly unfair to the painting which is a 2D surface telling a strange, familiar tale in a nonverbal language. Why drag it down thru Disney theme park muck? Hopper paintings in particular are frustrating to curators because they are so simple, straightforward, and implacable. You can’t really talk about them without breaking the power of their silence so why not build a dollhouse around one? The life sized reproduction of what the painting was partly alluding to will yield an experience of a space more or less related to, but clearly not of the original painting. So this is meant as a different way to experience the painting. But, is that what you’re experiencing? No, yet it does dilute and pollute the painting by being part of a clown show.

data.alt: late night Magic table, stays t - thoskite | ello

body.data: What happens late night on the Magic table, stays on the Magic table. The photos here were from hidden cameras. When new game sketches stopped appearing, the cams were removed. Now, they’re forbidden.

When good drawing paper and a sharp pencil is left on the glass overnight, during certain times of the year things appear. In the morning for instance, everything needed to make a new kind of game is all laid out in sketches on blank paper of the night before. It’s no surprise that the designs fade away in a couple of hours. Making games from magic table drawings can be a bit tricky, but what do you expect with magic stuff?

Dance magic dance…

A number of the glass blocks pictured above are now gone courtesy of the hurricane, but the magic table made it through (again). body.data: You’re looking at 3D designs for 3Dprinting prototypes for an injection molded version of PeltaPeeps. Why do that? Well, it went like this-

But it’s too expensive. No, it’s UV printed, laser cut acrylic- everybody loves the way they feel. Don’t you want more people to play it? Sure. Then do something about it. Tried die cutting and the design suffers. Even then- the pieces don’t have weight. Tactile appeal is lost. There’s injection molding the pieces? Got $40,000 to find out? 

We could teach the dog to bark Handel’s Messiah and sell tickets. Monkeys just started flying out of your ass so it just might work!

Our 3D printer’s precision is too lame to make decent ABS parts, but at least we can try out relief designs, sizes, and stuff while the dog takes voice lessons.

data.alt: Georgia charcoal homage long ch - thoskite | ello

body.data: Georgia was a charcoal homage to Georgia O’Keeffe done in a different long ago when chaos was a friend, not an enemy. It became a 3x4’ plate glass etching mounted on solid maple blocks (below) for a master’s thesis show completing a MA in Studio Fine Art. Got a little too exposed to the wrong kind of acid making this.

The promised MFA never materialized in time to add a few more credits and acquire another piece of paper whose value was as questionable as it gets. At least it only took 10 years to pay off the student loan.

So the charcoal drawing was destroyed in a fire a few years after graduation. And the heavy maple blocks for the sculpture were left behind after the 3rd or 4th of endless moves. But, the etching is still whole with only a small piece broken off a lower corner of the plate glass. Ground the sharp edges off the break and it waits in a crate to feel playful moonlight pour thru it once more.
Recently, laser engraved & painted a mirror (below) of the Georgia design which turned out as questionable as the nonexistent MFA program. (detail of laser pattern above)

data.alt: PeltaTESS- color spread pattern - thoskite | ello

body.data:
PeltaTESS- there's a thing that happens when color is spread around in a pattern. Color ends up camouflaging the pattern. 

Someone playing with that pattern has to manage switching back and forth between thinking of color on the one hand and shape symmetries on the other. In other words, they must keep in mind two competing views at the same time. This acquired skill is useful and seems rewarding for its own sake.

A puzzle that's a game, based on the stuff above, that also has multiple structured and unstructured solutions which can be explored solo or with others, is evergreen. Kinda like making art... without the occasional pain in the butt. data.alt: Black FAIL series called “Forbi - thoskite | ello

body.data: Black Gold’s a FAIL from a series called “Forbidden Fruit” which combines glass fusing and lamp worked raindrops. The black glass raindrops (below) sit on top of the glass because they haven’t been fused yet.

Unfortunately, this panel broke in the kiln because the gold ‘fruit’ shapes in the center, were fused with real gold (leaf), first. This was an early try at working glass and gold. Didn’t know that gold changed the COE of the glass, but found out in the 2nd firing that the panel couldn’t take the stress of now incompatible glasses cooling together. The image below shows what the raindrop effect looks like after a successful fuse of a different piece (same series).

Cutting the red hands out of art glass sheet using a diamond ring saw was a stinker, so never got around to trying a do-over. But if it ever happens- now know what NOT to do... data.alt: Cape Cod studio, bunch cabinets - thoskite | ello

body.data: In the Cape Cod studio, a bunch of these cabinets were made with different panels that ran the gamut from serious stuff to ones that were more about putting food on the table.

This one has a kiln formed, clear plate glass nautilus design in a leaded glue-chip and hand blown ruby art glass panel. The wall cabinet has glass shelves and mirrored back. Usually, they had brass hardware and either glass or porcelain knobs.
Be damned if some of the ones on the groceries side, didn’t turn out better than the rest.
At least this one sort of did. (Interior view of door panel- above. Slumped glass- below.)

So necessity is the mother of what-the-hell... Related Posts: Nautilus panel Spirals Keeper Unlikely Lovers @elloart @elloblog @ellodesign @ellomakers @ellowrites @ellotextures @altered_images #texture #makers #art #glass #goldenspiral #artglasstk #functionalart #functional #cabinet

data.alt: Nautilus leaded panel German op - thoskite | ello

body.data: Nautilus is a leaded panel using German opalescent, French grey crackle, and English streaky glasses. So the Nautilus shell is a natural spiral that is similar to the golden ratio and specifically, the Fibonacci spiral. However, this is disputed by eggheads who say while it is a logarithmic spiral, it ain’t a golden one cuz the ratio is off.

Above- the green spiral is made from quarter-circles tangent to the interior of each square (Fibonacci), while the red spiral is a Golden Spiral, a special type of logarithmic spiral. Overlapping portions appear yellow. The length of the side of one square divided by that of the next smaller square is the golden ratio. So it is close enough for people who aren’t suffering from OCD. Of course nautili everywhere think they’re just a bunch of mollusk haters. data.alt: rare, handmade glass flashed st - thoskite | ello

body.data: An even more rare, handmade glass is a flashed streaky. They are harder to engrave because it's intimidating to work on material that's hard to find, expensive, and difficult to engrave due to its variations in thickness, random pattern, and changes in color density/depth.

From a series called Bioforms, this green English streaky, flash glass was ground and polished clear in a band across the bottom. Then the design was wheel engraved in the intaglio style (no brilliant cutting). The leaded border glass is a streaky opalescent. data.alt: Snowy Owl acid etched heavy pla - thoskite | ello

body.data: Snowy Owl is acid etched heavy plate glass 36x24x¾ inches. About 40 years ago, concentrated hydrofluoric was used to remove a layer of glass and polish the etched surface.

The acid is highly corrosive and also a powerful contact poison penetrating tissue. Poisoning occurs quickly through exposure of skin or eyes, or when inhaled/swallowed. The fumes are as dangerous as the liquid. Lime is used to neutralize it. You really have to watch your ass around this stuff because it interferes with nerve function. So a bad burn may not even be initially painful. Stopped making pieces with it after this panel. data.alt: Embarrassments Venus II leaded  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Embarrassments of Venus II is a leaded glass panel of beveled, etched, & opal glass. It has 8 glass eyes- style, human. Some of these were recovered from broken, antique, hand blown glass eyes and ground to fit the design.

Embarrassments of Venus (above), shares a window with some other glass and sculpture in the Maine barn studio. Had to rebuild the barn, a 40 x 40 ft, storey and a half to the eaves, post and beam built before the Civil War. It had been turned into a chicken barn in the more recent past by adding a couple of floors. After tearing out the floors coated in ancient chicken shit, jacked up one side of the building with 2 twenty ton house jacks to get it level again, and rebuilt where needed. Made a damn fine studio. data.alt: post, drawing decided design up - thoskite | ello

body.data: Doing this post, an old drawing decided to try a little design update. Maybe a riff on all those years spent in a zippered portfolio. But instead, the result (above) seems a ripened version of the original.

Looking back is a rearview where nothing's mutable. Yet, it’s useful for a maker to do so when what was made calls. "Embarrassments of Venus" is a drawing made 40 years ago by a very different, but sorta same person. Unsure of many things, there was a consuming urge to make- no change there.  Swirling thoughts about enough talent, skill, knowing art, and other useless things would interfere with making then and for some time to come.

The original above began on a large sheet of Rives BFK with deckle edges. It's 100% rag surface was smooth and white- the perfect blank of a new snowfall. Paper scent as inviting as hot, fresh bread beckoned. The pencil drawing unfolded then, returning gaze for gaze until it was clear- making is when something from beyond and all around, comes to you. In that lucid moment, it leaps into being- a completed reality already drifting away. Of course, it's also about the embarrassments of Venus. There are many kinds of that- like enough talent, skill, knowing art, and other useless things that interfere with making. body.data: A & B Divide was the 1st sculpture to explore alabaster and glass. 2 surplus, US Army, tank periscope prisms were engraved and ground to fit the stone.
Optical grade glass is usually a lot harder than ordinary plate which is harder than most art glass so some damaged prisms were used for practice before these were made.
This opened up a fertile new world of shapes being reflected, cut up, and rearranged as you walk around an object. Think house of mirrors.

Unfortunately, this one was destroyed in the move from the Maine studio to the West Coast. PeltaWorld is a game that’s been in the works for going on 3 years, thru hurricane, pandemic, digging out, packing, moving, setting up studios, and doing it all over again. While that was going on, it was slowly getting settled on how the game would let you play out the human farce that is climate change tragedy.

data.alt: PeltaWorld game works 3 years,  - thoskite | ello

body.data: But, the PeltaPeeps, (actors for human players in-game), knew as they helped make the game steadily better- 2 problems remained. The 1st one was being stuck at 4 player only. The 2nd was related to the 1st, but seemed to be about better modeling the reality of human failure via extreme success. Problem 1 is an old one because games that work well for 4 players usually don’t for 2. And 3 player games are plagued by odd-man-out syndrome until the 3rd player is removed. Then the game’s end is reduced to a contest for 2 anyway. PeltaPeeps are good at recognizing the obvious when everyone else doesn’t. So they found the solution for both and it is asymmetry. (old board below)

They started by making the board out of 7, instead of 8, territory hexes. Now there are 3 pairs of game board territories, designed for each of 3 players. The 4th has only 1 territory hex.  That’s when all Hell broke loose-

(new board above). The player with only 1 territory will be at the center of the board which is a perfect place to mess with everyone else. PeltaPeeps, being who they are- started choosing sides and some smartass yelled, “the TeknoPeeps VS EkoPeeps! “ and a look of happy evil spread all across the dungeon. (old board play- below)

OK- so, have 1 player whose winning criteria are different than everyone else’s. Even better- those goals are in direct conflict with everyone else’s and vice versa. The TeknoPeeps build and grow and chase wealth while the EkoPeeps do whatever it takes to protect PeltaWorld from over development by TeknoPeeps! Meanwhile, the Teknos compete against each other, but they all want to get rid of the EkoPeep pests! Second highest score of victory points, still wins whether your're Eko or Tekno. The points just accrue for different and opposing goals. So problems 1 & 2 are solved with asymmetric territories, asymmetric player priorities, and asymmetric goals to win the game. So now there’s opportunity for solid 2, 3, and 4 player versions of the game because lopsided conflict is built into the game. Those PeltaPeeps are persistent buggers. @robert-copla there are 2 kinds of pieces the players can move around- the PeltaPeeps are round and have eyes,  The other kind of pieces are blade shapes-
Peeps move along the lines of circles on the board. And Blades move along blade shapes-

from the quikstart guide- >All pieces move along board paths of nearest adjacent shape matching their own. > Player moves any or all of their PeltaPeeps 1st then Blades. PeltaPeeps - > Move up to 3 spaces , Can jump once over pieces and non-circle spaces. Jump ends on the 1st vacant circle & counts as only 1 space moved. Removing another clan's piece ends that piece's movement. Blades - > Move up to 2 spaces, never jump (can't cross Realm Centers or Crossroads- must go around). PELTAs: 2 Blades Together - > 2 same color Blades facing make a PELTA that protects or surrounds. > Protects same color PeltaPeeps inside it from capture/removal. Surrounds other color PeltaPeeps who're then forced to retreat to their home Realm's Center.

@ellodesign thank you! pretty close- 1st you choose a wheel. this one started with a half miter cutting fishbone ribs. then a smaller full miter wheel cut the whiskers while a 3rd larger strapping wheel made the nose shape where all the whiskers meet. next, a radius wheel cut the oval shapes (called olives). and last, a wood wheel (shaped to match the radius wheel) was coated with a slurry of cerium oxide and water, to polish 2 of the olives making the brilliant cut eyes. then the sides were cut off to give the cut glass pane a semicircular shape.  

there are always many other engraving designs partly started up to almost finished on various glasses hanging around to switch to if the current design gets stuck. this was done in one sitting because it knew what it was from the beginning. most of them don't have that luxury.

data.alt: Unfinished Carrara marble sculp - thoskite | ello

body.data: Unfinished Carrara marble sculpture later left at the bottom of a pool next to a stream behind the Maine studio. At 170 lbs per cubic foot, it and a few other stone sculptures had to be left behind when we closed the studio.

On moving in, used a backhoe to make a small pool the stream behind the barn could feed. In only a year, cattails sprung up, forest critters stopped by for a drink, and summer frogs gave nightly concerts. So it seemed a fitting place to return to the earth that which came from an Italian quarry half a world away.
Stone’s a lot different than glass. There’s no distance between you and it which could be why there’s a bigger hole in you when it’s left behind.

But, no worries, in a thousand years, it may still be there. So it’s not like really completely lost or anything. data.alt: Theory sculpture combining ston - thoskite | ello

body.data: The Theory of Everything is a sculpture combining stone & glass on a steel base. The glass is lamp worked/engraved Pyrex and the stone is alabaster. Apparently, it’s keen on clockwise rotation.
Alabaster is a soft stone compared to granite and even softer then marble. It also usually has a more translucent surface than marble.

The Theory of Everything (TOE) is a sought for, all-encompassing, theoretical framework of physics that explains and links all stuff in the universe. The idea of one started with Einstein who tried, but failed to find a unifying theory for gravity (general relativity) and electromagnetism.

Up to now, a lot of predictions made by general relativity and quantum mechanics have been experimentally confirmed, but general relativity and quantum mechanics are mutually incompatible at this point.

However, this sculpture was made over 30 years ago and even though a lot’s been learned since, it’s still the only real deal. Yes! - you’re looking at the actual Theory of Everything. It’d have a frickin’ Nobel Prize by now, but only a select few know of its existence which is just fine… So shush! data.alt: “Replacement Geryon Stego-clops - thoskite | ello

body.data:
The Geryon of Dante's Inferno isn’t the original in the Greek tale where Heracles had to travel to Erytheia and steal the Cattle of Geryon after killing him with a poison arrow. 

No, the Inferno Geryon is a monster of Fraud with dragon wings, lion paws, a scorpion's stinger, and the face of an "honest man". Geryon rises from Hell’s circles of violence and fraud to ferry Virgil and Dante back down to the depths of the 8th Circle of Hell where the sin of Fraud is punished for all eternity.

In this print, Geryon is replaced by a Stegoclops (stegosaurus/Cyclops) and accompanied by a headless sphinx spider.

data.alt: GIFed series cast art glass cal - thoskite | ello

body.data: GIFed from a series of cast art glass called "Memes", done in 2005. The idea of memes started with Jacques Monod, a French biologist who shared a Nobel Prize in 1965. He proposed an analogy: just as the biosphere stands above the world of nonliving matter, so an “abstract kingdom” rises above the biosphere- it’s the kingdom of ideas.

Monod wrote, “Ideas have retained some of the properties of organisms. Like them, they tend to perpetuate their structure and to breed; they too can fuse, recombine, segregate their content; indeed they too can evolve, and in this evolution selection must surely play an important role.”
Richard Dawkins proposed the term, “meme” as a name, possibly from the words “memory” (idea) and “gene” (coded attributes/behaviors). Ideas need a host like human memory to live in and propagate.

From: What Defines a Meme? “… Whether an idea arises uniquely or reappears many times, it may thrive in the meme pool or it may dwindle and vanish. The belief in God is an example Dawkins offers—an ancient idea, replicating itself not just in words but in music and art. The belief that Earth orbits the Sun is no less a meme, competing with others for survival. (Truth may be a helpful quality for a meme, but it is only one among many.)…”

Nowadays, shock and fear appear to be the successful meme’s preferred weapons of survival and growth. That’s one of the reasons why the internet has turned into such a shithole. Google and facebook are the other ones. data.alt: Moon Snail alabaster glass scul - thoskite | ello

body.data: Moon Snail is an alabaster and glass sculpture with a patinaed steel base, all done in the Maine studio. There are cutouts in both the stone and steel that fit an engraved optical prism which came from a military surplus of armored tank periscopes.
Real moon snails have beautiful shells. The critter itself is a bit on the nasty side and downright butt-ugly, especially if you’re a careless clam which is their favorite fruit.
They take their time drilling a hole in the clam’s shell and then it’s dinnertime. Looks like the only thing slower than a snail is a sleeping clam.

Interesting how beautiful and heartless Nature is. No wonder humans are such a nightmare. That said- getting a bit peckish... Could really go for some steamed clams, raw oysters, or a side of snails in garlic butter… with a nice Chianti... and some fava beans... data.alt: Fuse Casting Glass Blocks- star - thoskite | ello

body.data: Fuse Casting Glass Blocks- start with Art glass billet, 1 x 5 x 10 inches, each. Cut them up and make a stack you like. Lay the stack on its side in a glass kiln. Put dams around it and fuse the glass at 1500 degrees F to make a single big block.
Let big block anneal and cool slowly over several days.
Cut the big block in quarters. Rearrange and fuse them together again.
Rinse and repeat fusing one more time- big block cut into 4 blocks.
Then cut each of the 4 blocks into 9- 2 inch cubes each.

Grind and polish 6 sides of each 2” cube, resulting in 36 cubes in 4 sets of 9 each forming unique 9 cube patterns. Then get your head examined. data.alt: fossil riff; small, untitled, l - thoskite | ello

body.data: Another fossil riff; this small, untitled, leaded glass engraving is on etched gluechip with antique & opalescent border done in the Cape Cod studio. Different polishing wheels were used selectively to add visual depth to the physical depth of etched and engraved surfaces. Glass engraving was what really opened the door to spontaneous making because prior sketching of engraved designs becomes largely pointless. Nothing can quite capture how one glass cut will appear, especially in relation to another, except by making that next cut. So the foggier the initial idea, the better! It was then that preconceived notions of what you’re going to make became the enemy. The mind then gives in completely to the process and the material while focusing on every change and surprise taking place in real time. It’s like scoring and performing a new composition simultaneously. Seems the freedom found in such an approach is beyond words. data.alt: laser engraved painted mirror,  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Here in a laser engraved and painted mirror, male wave meets light wave means 3some trouble. Male Wave is based on Hokusai’s Japanese ukiyo-e prints of Male and Female waves.

Ukiyo-e is an art genre that spanned 17th to 19th century in Japan and is expressed in woodblock prints and paintings of history, folk tales, landscapes, and of course- erotica. The roots of Manga and Anime are in Ukiyo-e printmaking as it put art in the hands of ordinary people. And Ukiyo-e had a huge impact on the Impressionists in late 19th century Europe.

So ignoring all that- Hokusai’s Male and Female waves are cool designs that wanted a spin in the 21st century. The 1st step was to make reversed BMP, 2 bit files that work well for laser engraving glass. (Male above & Female BMP below)

Sometimes they switch and the Male BMP is on the bottom, but that’s another story. Well, the laser mirrors were painted with copper and placed in green wood frames which they both are very happy with as long as they are hung together. Isn’t that adorable?

Below is a picture of the Male Wave mirror hung on the right side of the doorway leading from the dining room to living room. The Female Wave mirror is quite happily hung on the left side of the same doorway (off camera in this shot).

One day last Spring, domestic bliss was suddenly blown asunder by a horny sunbeam bursting in via the porch windows! It grabbed the Male Wave’s reflection and flung it across the room, smack against the new wall cabinets!!  There it stayed wantonly shimmering- a frameless, shameless, naked male, mirror mirage- right across from the now startled Female Wave mirror. Then, without a second thought, she instantly reflected his torrid photons of lust!

In just a 3way moment or two, the Male Wave’s randy reflection vanished, damage done. The 2 mirrors haven’t spoken to each other since. The other day, we had a sit down talk with both of them and found out they really aren’t mad at each other at all- just embarrassed about being super freaky. So we explained that kind of stuff isn’t for everyone and if they’re uncomfortable about it or instead, want to experiment, it’s totally OK either way as long as they use safe words so nobody gets hurt more than they want to... Now, everything’s mostly fine. At least, the 2 perverts are back together again. And the romantic moral to the story: “Never get involved in…

data.alt: Samurai sand carved (sandblaste - thoskite | ello

body.data: Samurai is sand carved (sandblasted) ¾ inch plate glass in a wrought iron stand. The iron work was done in Cape Cod for an etched glass panel and cut down about 10 years later to fit the Samurai panel.
Not a fan of sandblasting as applied to glass because it doesn’t really work the intrinsic beauty of the medium.
This is 1 of only 3 sandblasted pieces ever done by this maker as the process is a bit of a pain in the butt, so no surprise when the result confirms it.

But samurai and iron is a natural combination so it could be worse. At least the design made an effort to get the armor correct and reference classic poses in Japanese Art and Noh Theater. Yea, maybe this design could be a fused glass panel someday… with the armor stacked up in layers to get a gleaming, deep, relief effect… oh… wow… could be pretty intense with a little luck. data.alt: UV printing action: light hits  - thoskite | ello

body.data: UV printing action: UV light hits the block surface as ink jets put down acrylic ink- instantly cured on contact. Each side is- reverse printed with 1 design, then 3 layers of white, and then the 2nd design- face up.
1 design faces in and the other faces out (Above picture). Inward facing designs are seen thru the transparent, unprinted sides of each block.
Final version is nine, 2" clear acrylic cubes, UV printed w/ the same 6 designs as the wood blocks. But, instead of printing all 6 sides- only 3 adjacent sides are printed.

Talk about uncarved blocks- 3D & UV is a hoot! body.data: This BMP was made for a Fusilli design, laser engraved, and painted mirror in maple cabinet. The mirror is 18x18 inches.
After the laser engraves the glass, having burned thru mirror backing, the back was painted in copper and black (in the above image the white areas are mirror).

Fusilli mirror in lower kitchen cabinet. The mirror colors are meant to work with the cherry butcher block counter tops. The mirror brings reflected color and movement to the image so it's always changing. body.data: GIFed some old photos of untitled alabaster & engraved glass sculpture done in Maine barn studio. Glass is a 2.5 inch double convex lens, engraved on both sides with a brilliant cut insect design on one side and intaglio notching on the other.
The stone’s about the size of a human hand. The lens rests in a groove in the stone much like it would if held between your index finger and thumb along its edge.

It’s about the wonder you had as a kid and bugs and shining drops of water and magic light everywhere when all was new. data.alt: Growing pack poodles including  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Growing up, we had a pack of poodles including one named Alice B. Toklas- but everyone called her Alice. She was a light color called champagne. There were 3 in the pack- all standard poodles (the big ones).

Yogi and Hunter were the other two. Yogi was named for the famous picnic bear. And Hunter was named so because he’d been Hunter Thompson's dog. We got the dog from him via Bill Kennedy, another writer.
The story was- Hunter, the writer, became allergic to Hunter, the dog's fur. But, it seemed more like the other way around with the dog allergic to the writer's LSD.
Even after detox, Hunter the dog was fluffy black outside, but still gonzo paisley on the inside... That's Life, so the people say…
@monique2211 thanks! been enjoying your images, especially one of your latest!

@ddailey thanks! well along with all that, it's actually true. Poor Hunter was so wired the whites of his eyes showed for the longest time. Even when that stopped and he'd gotten completely at home with us and the other dogs, you had to be careful how you played with him. 

He could flip out if you played too energetically. Once bit the hell out of one of my brothers who stirred him up too much. Surprised he got mad at the dog. What the hell did he expect? -but that's another completely uninteresting story.
@novaexpress93 life is always interesting as a kid. the trick is keeping that way over the long haul. but hell, dreamers know about that- nice!!!

@wandering_mind
well musta been some good shit!

Here’s a slumped and engraved plate glass spirit animal of the Horseshoe crab. We asked the Horseshoe crab’s spirit animal to influence the glass as it began forming when the kiln reached 1,100 degrees F.

data.alt: slumped engraved plate glass sp - thoskite | ello

body.data: But, the spirit animal of Stingrays butted in, shutting off the kiln too soon (faked a power failure). So the glass took the shape of the crab spirit instead of the crab! Now, it’s still mad at us because it thinks it’s our fault.

That’s why a hurricane destroyed our studio and made us move inland from our dream home on a bayou next to the sea. OR the real story is- we knew climate change is going to batter the hell out Florida before it drowns her. So, we took a calculated risk moving there with a dash of hope all the slimy politicians would finally do the right thing and save the planet instead of lining their pockets when they aren’t molesting anything breathing (not breathing is ok too, if recently deceased). But all that wasn't a very good idea, now was it. Moral: Stingrays, like politicians, can be a Titanic type of pain in the ass. data.alt: 3 stacks blocks 2 double, rever - thoskite | ello

body.data: Of the 3 stacks of blocks here- 2 are double, reverse printed clear acrylic and the set in between those is single printing on birch wood. Took 64 shots of them going around and cut that to 48 to make a loop. The lighting was bad so processed the images. The resulting GIF not so much (way worse than the one above).

So this was done because the videos were disappointing. Or the turntable was disappointing and the lighting was bad. Or it was a tired idea in the 1st place- trying to post how thoroughly fun it is to fool around with these damn things.

Then it hits you that what you’re doing is beyond absurd. But promptly ignoring all that, you throw out everything and start over with new images from shooting in full sunlight on a day with thunderstorms (makes it more thrilling especially wearing a tinfoil hat).

Why? Because when it isn’t good enough, you fumble around until it is. You also never met anyone who's satisfied. Really, who the hell even wants to be satisfied?! When you’re completely dead there’s plenty of time for that. :)

After all, making stuff is all about how good it feels after- like when you stop hitting yourself in the head with a hammer. And you can’t wear out a hammer, so no downside.

data.alt: Eye glass sculpture started lif - thoskite | ello

body.data: Emerson's Eye is a glass sculpture who started life as a Red wine bottle, a big one. First, it had to be emptied which was just one more sacrifice at the feet of mistress Art. Happily, she doesn't mind if those under her spell get a good buzz on, but only for beauty's sake. right? right. booty's sake? no. BbbuuuuTeey- got it? right.

Empty, you would think there’s not a damn thing that an Italian Chianti bottle and a dead New England minister wannabe would have in common. Well, the bottle bottom had leanings toward Transcendentalism.
Sure enough with the help of a diamond bandsaw, diamond lap, and the big glass engraver running 24 inch stone wheels, out popped a transparent eye from being trapped within that bottle glass.

Bet old Waldo and Henry looking down from their cabin in the sky, got a kick out of how it turned out. Yep, repurposing a bottle from the trash into something you have the nerve to call sculpture is about as green as you can get.

Except windmills, they would be greener… or solar panels… or backyard veggie gardens or a carbon tax or no more god damned plastic in the oceans or maybe hundreds upon hundreds of other things… Related Posts: Horseshoe spirit Bug eye Terrapin Dwindling pack ice @elloart @elloblog @ellodesign @ellomakers @ellowrites @ellotextures @altered_images #texture #makers #art #glass #engraving #artglasstk #nature #sculpture #wine #cabin #hurricane #green #climatechange #humanfolly

data.alt: Wrote bunch crap glass medium m - thoskite | ello

body.data: Anyway, the glass mask above was cut out of a bourbon bottle using a diamond wet saw. It was then engraved with a number of small, differently shaped diamond and stone wheels, spinning much slower than typical grinding wheels. This is to keep cooling water from spinning off the wheel for even a moment because sudden heat can destroy hours and hours of effort. Glass work requires understanding the nature of things and randomness. It doesn’t mean you get used to it.

Glass objects live in a universe of chaos and destruction solely dependent on chance to exist a little while or thousands of years. Compare this to the arc of one person's life or even humanity at large. Although inorganic and organic can't be mistaken, the similarity of condition is crystal clear. So yes Virginia, still a bunch of crap, but way shorter :) Related Posts: Interlopers Shaken not stirred Emerson’s eye @altered_images @thewriting-group @ellodesign @ellomakers @ellotextures @ellowrites #texture #makers #art #artist #designer #design #glass #sculpture #artglasstk #sculpture3Dtk #truth #bullshit #masks #discourse #recycled #alteredstates #GIF

data.alt: 3 shots sculpture. tiny white o - thoskite | ello

body.data: All 3 of these shots are of the same sculpture. The tiny white opal glass rod that made it possible is called stringer. Glass is about surface tension. Think rain hitting a windshield at 60 miles per hour and still pulling itself together enough to slide off as a round droplet. That’s how powerful it is. It’s this tension that gives thin glass stringer strength.
In fact, the smaller glass is the more flexible it becomes. Who cares? Well, for one thing, the glass does because it will do outrageous things when it’s small enough, even at room temperature.
Example- heat glass stringer in a flame (Lampworking) and twist it around to make a spring shaped spiral. Let it cool and it can stretch some and spring back like a real spring, without shattering!

Hell, if it wasn’t for the crazy stuff glass can do when it’s the thickness of a human hair, the internet wouldn’t be able to deliver all the bullshit it does currently… oh… damn... !! This is NOT about glass shaming or blaming, so haters hating hating- begone !! jezus... Ok, so you have to take the good with the sad. data.alt: colorful opal glass sculpture l - thoskite | ello

body.data: This colorful opal glass sculpture made of lampworked stringer is sitting on a kiln cast, glass panel table top. The glass panel behaves like you expect glass to act. The stringer sculpture does not. Yes, it is fragile, but amazingly, it can bend or bounce without breaking, at least up to a point.

The table top and sculpture grew to be close friends, so for a few wonderful years they were inseparable. Sadly, the sculpture did break in a move, but when you’re glass you know all along how it will end. 

At least the table top, one of a pair, is still doing its functional art thing, together with its mate. They reminisce about how lovely and lively dear stringer was.

Like all glass, stringer knows it’s not how long you are around, but what you do while you’re still in one piece. data.alt: tessellation squares laser engr - thoskite | ello

body.data: A tessellation of squares in squares was laser engraved on the glass of 17 cabinet doors for a custom Adler wood entertainment wall. The design was meant to be see thru, but strong enough to filter what’s inside.
The engraving was exactingly laid out to appear as one continuous pattern from side to side and top to bottom in a 10x8 foot set of 5 cabinets designed for the glasswork.
The glass shelves are 3/8 inch thick to carry books or sculpture. The cabinet under the flat screen is deep enough for AV equipment.

The cabinet above the flat screen is deep enough to take oversize art books, but not as deep as the bottom one. The tall side cabinets on either side of the flat screen are a standard 1 foot deep with asymmetric door layouts just for the hell of it. Related: Kitchen laser foolishness More kitchen stuff Acrylic wine racks Face of AI @ello @ellodesign @ellomakers @thewriting-group @elloblog @elloart @ellotextures #texture #makers #making #art #artist #designer #design #laser #glass #wine #process #art #winerack #sculpture3Dtk #functionalart #laser #glass #engraving #artglasstk #GIF
@dabi thanks! like most the more old fashioned wheel engraving, but this design would have been almost impossible without a computer controlled laser.

@monique2211 Thanks! spent a day designing woodwork for the wall. the tessellating pattern came from a bunch of other work so have to guess that. can count the CAD time to setup the fullsize engraving patterns for each of the 17 panels at about 7 hrs. so maybe 16 hrs + laser time and installing the panels = 5.5 days total for the glass work. 

the woodwork was done by a cabinet shop. installing the 5 cabinets took another week because we had to run wiring for the LED lights, computer network, and AV stuff plus cut/install 14 glass shelves. so all totaled- 2.5 weeks to go from nothing to finished.

data.alt: GIF untitled grid, sand cast gl - thoskite | ello

body.data: This GIF close-up is of untitled grid, a sand cast glass sculpture with embedded glass rod in opal and transparent colors.
Sand casting involves pouring molten glass directly into a preformed greensand mold at temperatures around 2,000° F. It is similar to the process used for sand casting metal, so bronze age tech.

The mold detail was made by pressing a rubber grid into the damp greensand and then carefully removing it. Compatible lamp worked glass stringer was then arranged in the mold and molten clear glass ladled into it.

After casting, the glass was cut into an octagon, then ground, polished, and engraved. Last, it was mounted on a cherry wood base. But this post is close-ups only, to imagine a glass world flowing on in all directions as layers of fractal grids we live out our lives within… ecological, familial, social, moral, academic, economic, political, spatial, geographic, aesthetic, scientific, electric, cyber, subatomic, galactic, spiritual, spatiotemporal and on and on… Like the grids that you find in the windmills of your mind.

Used surplus optical glass and both ends were ground and polished to a clear bevel that is the same angle as the prism sides. This created an edge that could be wrapped in copper foil and then soldered to form the leading with a cobalt blue, cathedral glass border. The piece size is about 2x6x14 inches.

data.alt: GIFed untitled metal sculpture  - thoskite | ello

body.data: GIFed an untitled metal sculpture made out of aluminum with bases in alternating copper and brass done in the 2nd Seattle studio. It’s 15x4x16 inches overall. (GIF best viewed while listening to music below-)

The bases were cut from ½ inch thick x 3 inch bar stock and drilled for brass rod to support the 4 aluminum disks. 
The disks were cut freehand on a metalworking bandsaw from 4 inch diameter rod. They were then deburred, smoothed, and lightly polished to a satin texture that captures the light.

The 4 disks have undulating and varying thicknesses while retaining their smooth cylindrical dimension. NOTE: There was zero intent to make robot lollipops or some complex statement about the human need to stand in lines. In fact, this is just the result of making something for the hell of it. (see Disclaimer) DISCLAIMER: No circles were harmed in the making of this work. However, the disks all got their bottoms drilled so they can sit on brass rods ‘til the end of time which may cause some viewers discomfort. If you experience such discomfort- close your eyes then put your right foot in, put your right foot out, and shake it all about…

That’s what it’s all about. data.alt: Angelfishbones Cape Cod studio  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Angelfishbones was made in the Cape Cod studio using French crackle, German opalescent, and wheel engraved plate glass. This one started the fishbones series. From here pieces got bigger and branched out into fossil stuff and slumped glass sculpture (see related below). Used to title and sign these with a diamond scribe because people think something is worth more if there’s a name on it.

Things have completely changed while staying the same since then. Pieces like this one never age, but the eyes and hands that made and 1st saw them do, until all that’s left is pieces like this one that never change until they do as well. Anyway, stopped signing stuff years ago. Turns out it's unimportant. data.alt: mental blocks, UV printed hollo - thoskite | ello

body.data:
More mental blocks, UV printed on hollow birch wood with unfortunate results. Scale is a much bigger problem than you would think at times. These are 4 inch cubes and they suck at that size which is an ugly surprise.

Seems when they are no longer small enough to nestle comfortably in the hand as hungry fingers slowly make gentle love to them, their magic is lost.

With larger scale, intimacy is traded off for the more formal, often pretentious, presence of sculpture. OK, so that could work, but only if size becomes really imposing which means greater than human scale. Cubes 9 feet/3 meters on a side should do it. That would make a 9 block set- 27’ tall by 27’ wide by 9’ thick.
  
Oh… yea. They could be made out of printed zeppelin fabric over light frames and filled with enough helium to weigh less than 100 lbs. each? Then they could be stacked and/or moved by those viewing them. Or internal electromagnets could be used to join the blocks into any arrangement desired. Or the blocks could float above the ground, set to neutral bouncy, and programmed to rearrange themselves in midair… sometimes randomly and other times completing one of the 6 different designs with music… even in outer space!

And we’re still stuck here when humans walked on the moon 52 years ago!? Could it be because we were so busy with goals far more important than exploring space- like perfecting self-abuse for over 5 decades while trashing the planet? The answer my friends is blowing in the wind… Related: Touch Congratulations Acrylic blocks REDfish BLUfish @ellomakers @elloart @ello @elloblog @ellowrites @thewriting-group #3D #gifs #puzzle #uncarvedblock #makers #gif #gamesarttk #sculpture3Dtk

data.alt: Bioforms XIV, series, friendly  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Bioforms XIV, like all the others in the series, got off from getting friendly with zooplankton. So who cares? You do, but you may not know it. Plankton covers all the tiny life that drift in the water column of all oceans, rivers, lakes, ponds, and puddles everywhere. This life is the basis of the global marine food web! Screw with plankton and go hungry.

And 50-80% of the oxygen production on Earth comes from the ocean. The majority of this production is from oceanic plankton which means it gets worse when we know for a fact that climate change disrupts plankton in a major way.

Also, they are kind of beautiful when you get to know them. The name comes from the Greek word planktos, meaning "wanderer" or "drifter", in the following flavors-
Phytoplankton (plant), Zooplankton (animal), Mixoplankton (animals that act like plants and/or vice versa), Mycoplankton (free-living fungi and yeasts), Bacterioplankton (bacteria), and Virioplankton (virus).

Above are members of gelatinous zooplankton: (a) Nemertean. (b) Phaeodarian radiolarian. (c) Salp with parasitic copepod. (d) Lobate ctenophore. (e). Narcomedusan hydrozoan. (f) Nudibranch mollusc. (g). Chaetognath. (h) Physonect siphonophore. (i) Coronate scyphozoan. (j) Polychaete. data.alt: glass mask (unfinished) cut red - thoskite | ello

body.data: But- Mark Twain's Works, Author's National Edition- 25 Vol. Set, printed 1911, wasn’t spared filthy storm water that soaked every volume to the bone. With everything else wet, there was no way to stop mold from rapidly finishing the job. On opening each, a wonderful smell of old books was now replaced with the fetid stink of a sewer as each volume fell apart. Recall reading every one of them as solace during a difficult time only to see them end like this. It comes down to a glass mask, as fragile as it is, being luckier than twenty-five, 110 year old books. The glass thinks of it this way- Chaos is the natural state of being. Being is existing briefly without belonging. Belonging is an illusion of stability within chaos. data.alt: Starting homage Piet Mondrian,  - thoskite | ello

body.data: Starting as homage to Piet Mondrian, this heavy art glass panel was kiln cast at the Seattle studio in 2006. It is 15 x 15.75 x .75 inches overall and weighs about 17 lbs. Thick glass billet, frit (ground up glass), and stringer were fused together at 1500 degrees F. Then the edges were trimmed and ground to a satin finish with a small bevel all around to help protect it from chipping if mishandled. (below: photo of the finished glass)

But, while making up the various parts of the piece for casting, it became clear the Mondrian thing was OK as starting point only. The glass would be damned if it stuck to the script- really… a bunch of squares and lines and primary colors in glass? You got to be kidding- screw that. Glass can be pretty rude sometimes. UPDATE: It has come to our attention that the maker of this travesty has been formally charged with attempted deconstruction of Minimalism. Please keep back and look away! data.alt: Sounding Whale leaded glass pan - thoskite | ello

body.data: Sounding Whale is a leaded glass panel that was placed in a cabinet made out of maple. The leaded panel uses French crackle, clear plate, opalescent, engraved flash, ruby, and streaky glasses with a mirrored cabinet back and glass shelves inside.
The door has a glass door knob, brass hinges, and a brass latch.

It was created in the Cape Cod studio as a gift for a family member years ago and now have no idea who has it. More than 10 years after it was made, we were in the middle of Puget Sound on a windy, winter day in a small motor boat, when a pod of orca whales came straight toward us, swimming from the north. Killed the engine, drifted, and before long, a mother and baby swam past within arm’s length, rolling on their sides to get a better look at the humans they passed by.

There are no words to describe what their eyes conveyed. Sat there, stunned, for a while afterward... then started the engine to return to our little world and our insignificant lives.

Making this post started because there are some objects you think back on and wonder about, like where they are- not that it matters much. 

Hell, looks like most things are really nothing at all compared to unfathomable encounters on a winter afternoon in a small boat, engine killed, drifting… 
-in an outer spiral arm of the galaxy called the Milky Way...

data.alt: sculpture series grids, bored f - thoskite | ello

body.data: Here’s a sculpture that came out of a series about grids, but got bored with flat planes. So it got busy by first slumping heavy plate glass in a mold made to create surface textures while also tack fusing dozens of different color stringer (thin glass rod) to the plate. Then it went back in the glass kiln for a 2nd round to be further slumped in a different mold, shaping it into a compound curve. Finally, the edges were ground and polished.

All this was done a second time because the 1st one thought it was only half of an S shape. That and it hoped people would be fooled into thinking it was a real sculpture, not just 2 high-handed hunks of glass.

You see, glass has a bit of an inferiority complex about not being considered an Art medium for the longest time. Of course, if you think squat of the art establishment or the latest bullshit art fad isn’t worth a fart in a gale of wind- then no worries. 

But, ten billion butterfly sneezes would be a different story-

This fused & slumped artglass test combining 2 sheets clear & opal green rod with 14K gold leaf between, is one of those lessons in futility. Venetian glass has used gold for centuries in functional pieces like goblets and jewelry like glass beads. And it's likely they didn’t invent it either, so this is hardly new.

data.alt: fused slumped artglass test com - thoskite | ello

body.data: It is interesting, but expensive to fool around with real gold. Also, found out the hard way that gold seriously changes the glass when it fuses into it. Glass that was originally compatible is no longer when fusing a 2nd or 3rd time. So, adding more original, non-gold glass in a 2nd firing results in it all going to smash as it cools. There are ways around this, but it makes things a lot more difficult. Back Gold (below) was a work in progress (about the effect of any costly resource torn from the earth) that broke later, cooling in the kiln-

The other, big problem is- why the hell put gold in glass in the 1st place? Well, gold is used to make red colored glasses such as "Ruby" and "cranberry glass". OK, and maybe gold leaf or powder in beads for jewelry makes some sense, but drinking glasses to impress- “oh yes, that’s real gold in the stemware dear...”- doesn’t make the wine taste any better. The real problem is, it’s one of those materials that just take over everything it touches. And glass has some of that problem as well. So putting them together is doomed to disappoint as the cost goes up up up… especially the human one. When you handle the delicate, incredibly thin leaf, it’s hard not to think of the blood on it. Have enough leaf to try to make the Black Gold panel again, but to be honest- been avoiding it for about 15 years because it’s clear using gold to make a statement about the underlying ugliness of gold seems as ass backwards as an ass can get. And when the medium you love, tells you not to do something- ignoring it is really asking for trouble. body.data: Spoiler- this post is not about art unless you think staying alive is part of making art. (rant) It’s now pretty clear that my partner’s stroke over 3 months ago is stress related, due to dealing with a mountain of shit flying over the last few years. Adrenaline is a hormone released under stress. This stress response prepares your body to take incoming damage (fight) or get the hell out of trouble fast (flight). So, it’s no surprise that Adrenaline increases blood coagulation factors to help stop bleeding faster than normal. By doing this, Adrenaline also increases the chance of clotting that causes stroke (see video at the end of this rant). Her doctors won’t stay current on unbiased research or they would know this. None of them do or if they do, will NOT admit it. This is also why they have not been able to find the cause of her stroke after all the tests, (another endless revenue stream). Never mind that they are looking for the wrong things. OK, doctor who has sworn to “do no harm”- let’s now prescribe medicine that will make things worse by interfering with the body’s natural ability to heal and fight disease while offering ugly and dangerous side effects. And if your patients object, threaten and bully them with- “if you don’t take this pill, you will die. Of course, the choice is yours.” Between big pharma, insurance companies, and complicit doctors - the medical system in the USA is not just venal and abusive, it’s criminal. So screw all the avaricious drug companies, insurers, and most of all- willing doctors with your blood on their hands. Take responsibility for your health because you’re pretty much on your own, especially when money is involved. (end of rant)

data.alt: Eve “Adam Eve”, diptych 2 fused - thoskite | ello

body.data: This is Eve from “Adam & Eve”, a diptych of 2 fused glass panels roughly 2 x 3 feet, each. The panels got started as torso forms cut out of color sheet art glass, (below). Then those layers were covered with 4 more layers of clear plate glass strips and body shapes which were fused in the kiln in a single firing.

So now, more than a dozen years later, Eve wants to strut her stuff online, but Adam is a bit shy due to excessive potty training. Actually, Eve and Adam have taken a while to get the nerve to be posted at all because they are definitely NSFW kids. In fact, there’re a few lines of naughty verse about them that apparently identify angels in a horny light! Just another example of how this whole Adam Eve thing isn’t at all what everybody has been lead to believe. But, sorry, the verse will only come out when Adam stops being such a wuss and appears online with Eve. See, Eve got this apple from an angel (no- that snake is total baloney), and now she’s pretty fearless, especially about anything new. Yea, of course we have all seen a lot worse here on smutty old ello in terms of sex, perverts, and sacrilege, but rarely in one neat package. So what’s the big deal? And, if angels are really horny, doesn’t that make it OK? Bloodlines II is a fused & slumped, art glass sculpture. These pictures were taken 5 years ago at the last Art show participated in to date. It got off on the wrong foot from the start.

data.alt: Bloodlines II fused slumped, ar - thoskite | ello

body.data: This 2 man show was composed of art glass by yours truly and a serigraph printmaker’s work for the other “artist”. So, of course, the show selection committee insisted on art glass only. No glass combined with other media would be allowed.

Apparently, there is some magical overlap between sculpture and prints that does NOT show up anywhere throughout Art history going back as far as cave painting. Yes! by God, it’s not allowed… maybe squirrels are somehow involved… or flying monkeys will be upset by too many notes?!! Needless to say, they wouldn’t budge a goddamned inch, regardless of the myriad, logical arguments that made it crystal clear how poorly thought out and arbitrary this dumbass decision was. Result: unfortunately some of the best work was excluded including glass with metal and/or stone, as well as a cast bronze sculpture called Olduvai. This is only 1 of several reasons this pilgrim doesn’t do shows NO more. Who needs the suffering fools bullshit? data.alt: designs Pelta Tessellation seri - thoskite | ello

body.data: One of the designs from the Pelta Tessellation series felt a little GIFfy after a hard night drinking radiused arc shooters. They make Romulan ale pale in comparison. Burp!

So this is all about circles and arcs and tessellating them with 2 different pelta-based tessellations which is as obsessive as it sounds. In the close-up above, the arcs and circles created on gray areas are two variations on the classic pelta (2 circles whose diameter is the radius of a larger circle that they fit inside).

The other tessellation within the yellow circles is a classic “fishscale“ pattern, derived from overlapping circles of equal radii. Above is a strip tessellation of all of them. data.alt: Touch years decide glass castin - thoskite | ello

body.data: Touch took several years to decide what it was. You see, glass castings are much like people because when they come out of the furnace and get poured into a mold, well that’s just the beginning.
About a year later, Touch felt too smooth so it got Battuto engraved over much of the relief side.

But it took another 3 or 4 years before it knew it was time to split, like in two, because there were two of them there, but they couldn’t touch! It’s what they needed most- to feel the other. Sound familiar? body.data: The Theory of Everything II is another old sculpture in a series combining stone and glass. The glass is lamp worked/engraved Pyrex and the stone is hand carved Colorado alabaster. Apparently, there are at least 2 sides to quantum objet d’art stuff.
The Theory of Everything (TOE) is an idea started by Al Einstein who tried, but failed to find a unifying theory for gravity (general relativity) and electromagnetism.

Theory of Everything II might just be the poster child/spirit animal of the duality of quanta. Unfortunately, it’s kinda like quantum mechanics- when you need 1- they’re never around. Forgot a simple rule about handling glass which is- always move slowly around glass. In other words, never pickup or otherwise mess with glass in haste or 1 of 3 things will happen- A) It will break, B) You will get hurt and blood will flow (yours), C) Both of the above. Unfortunately, you can’t move thru life slowly which could be why it wounds so...
