data.alt: titled, Sea Grass inspired driv - thoskite | ello

body.data: Yet, could it possibly be something in there that kind of works!? The turmoil of wind and waves washing through salt marsh might be there… or at least the ebb and flow at ocean edge...

Anyway, this leaded artglass eight ball of a 3x5 ft panel was a commission for a seaside house in Cape Cod, 40 years ago. Did do a couple of front door side lights along a similar theme for the very same house a year or two before making this window. They both use a combination of clear and opalescent glass with grinding or engraving. The difference is- the sidelights killed it on every level- the rhythm, the palette, the subtle symmetry- you name it!

1 thing’s for sure, love it or hate it- the most questionable pieces that you make are the ones that push boundaries the farthest. So it’s no surprise that you always learn the most from them. This sculpture started out as cast and cold worked glass modules for a Kinetic Installation.

data.alt: sculpture started cast cold wor - thoskite | ello

body.data: These were created to prototype a concept for a large installation potentially involving 100s of kinetic forms.

Forms moving thru time, the rebirth and entropy of that movement, and the interplay of randomness vs. synchronicity permeate nature. These studies were a step toward an installation that would explore such a landscape.

A Room w/ hundreds of these actuated by random generator software program was the end goal. Photo-eyes could tell a computer when all motion in the room has stopped and to then fire a new sequence. The program would be interactive in that viewers could change parameters to make more or less random the sequences. And the software would learn what settings are more popular so it can generate variations on them. More could be done from there- the introduction of special lighting (laser and/or LED) controlled by the same software and so on... But that never happened. data.alt: commission leaded glass panels  - thoskite | ello

body.data: This commission for leaded glass panels was made around 40 years ago in the Cape Cod studio for the front door of a house in New England.
The drawing was approved and the 1st step was to assemble the different glasses that were cut by hand to fit a linear lead pattern requiring over a hundred shapes.
Care was taken during the initial drawing to design a very strong interlocking pattern of shapes because these panels must handle the stress of life in an exterior door.
Next, the cut pieces that were to be cold worked, (engraved, etched, brilliant cut, beveled and/or hand ground), were made and placed in the soldering layout with the rest of the glass pieces.

Then, the panels were finished using the Tiffany style of leading by wrapping each piece's edges in copper foil and soldering them all together. This leading style produces a much lighter and stronger support than the far older lead came method which dates back to medieval times.
Medieval. Yea, such will seem our times if anyone’s still around just 800 years from now. So- row row row your boat…

@wandering_mind thanx! door work is tricky becuz the panels have to be able to take a beating from temp changes and not just open and closing, but the occasional slam from happy kids or pissed off parents or the wind, etc. 

in other words, it's a really dumb idea to put leaded panels in a door to begin with. But what the hell... if that's what somebody can't be talked out of then u beef it up. Did manage to get them to agree to 2 panel layout which is inherently much stronger than a single large one that wouldn't work at all without several steel saddle bars.
@eatious thank you! someday we plan to visit Prague and part of that is to see all the wonderful glass!
@nikthursday most thankful 4 ur reputzture & lick!! Enjoying ur lovely ode to birds, nerds, and parties of turds!!

@scarlettjoy1 ur welcome and thanx! never saw the site, but was told they lived surrounded by woods. that came up when they talked about wanting to be able to see out while having some privacy too. glass has the inherent ability to draw in its surroundings, changing with every little variation of light or movement going on all around it. so there was an effort to suggest forms nature is fond of in the design.
@monique2211 thanks! really like the church image with framing that makes it almost a formal abstract!
@novaexpress93 thanks- the images are old and grainy from scanned film prints unfortunately. luv your Memories post! Been thinking about a major change and it brings up all sorts of old stuff.

@mikacuervo it was/is one of the best pieces made during that time. even got fussy with the 2 steel saddle bars (for strength). 

the bars are traditionally just straight horizontals attached to the frame and soldered to the leading in the panels. the bars here are meant to disappear by being bent to follow the lead pattern (see the red lines drawn in the pic below)-

data.alt: pieces time. fussy 2 steel sadd - thoskite | ello

body.data: bet those damn panels are as flat and in as good shape as the day they were made. Shouldn't need attention for at least 100 more years (unless there's an accident). after having done a fair amount of stained glass restoration, you know every detail of what's important in making something that will last longer than you do. with any luck they'll be around for centuries. :)_
@vinkonings sure would love to see it. do know what real stained glass means :)

@vinkonings sorry if it was a bit pedantic. 

yes, did all the stained glass restoration of the Die Stat Bad panel in the link and a bunch of other restoration including 3 years of work in a catholic church in Portland, Maine. That was the last restoration. To be honest, don't have the skills to feel comfortable matching museum quality brushwork.  

anyway, making new work is far more interesting and glass engraving with or without kiln work and/or mixed media is even more so because it an excuse to fool around with sculptural stuff- not just flat panels. 

looking forward to your pictures :)

yes been making leaded and other glass stuff a long time. all the posts here are stuff made by me over the last 45 yrs.  it kinda odd because all the art school stuff was a major in printmaking- mostly etching and engraving intaglio with some lithography. Those guys from Trinity college really messed things up because they got me got totally hooked on glass...

This saying goodbye GIF is of a tessellation that morphed into a pelta game board design a few years back. Between a hurricane, pandemic, and some other ugliness, we are pulling the plug on Peltagames and are selling off all our game making equipment at pennies on the dollar.

Been here before and losing money isn’t that hard to get over. It’s the time and buckets of effort wasted that would suck if they mattered. But, they don’t because making is the only thing that does...  

So bye, bye Peltagames, it was nice while it lasted.

data.alt: decades View Empire State Plaza - thoskite | ello

body.data: Several decades ago, View of Empire State Plaza was made as a 4x15 foot triptych commissioned for an upscale restaurant/bar across from the old state capitol building in Albany, New York.

The Cathedral of the Immaculate Conception, (far left side of plaza construction aerial below), and the Capitol building, (center of photo on right below), flank the Plaza on the south and north sides when looking at the complex from the east.
The side panels are of the Cathedral and the Capitol building with the center panel showing the then new Plaza between them.

The 3 glass panels were hydrofluoric acid etched, heavy plate glass, ¾ inch thick. The concentrated acid was used to remove a layer of glass while polishing the etched surface to a texture similar to the surface of icicles.

Since the acid’s a powerful contact poison, the fumes are as bad as the liquid. So even being very careful, this was the largest and 2nd to last work dumb enough to be done with this iffy technique, solely because it produces a surface that’s not possible any other way.

But, not sure how well this holds up in terms of design when the resulting glass surface has such an organic vibe while the Plaza architecture is anything but that. Now, it looks like the old buildings in the side panels seem to work better than the center. Of course, the ancient photo prints then scanned, don’t help either. And all the negatives are long gone. Anyway, learned the triptych was broken up when the place was sold by the owners. Apparently, they took the center panel with them. Have no idea whether the side panels are still there or got sold off. Such is life... Hopefully, whatever happened is better than them ending up in the Hudson River. Oops! Update 12/12/21- just found a picture from the original owners and turns out they took the 2 side panels to keep for themselves when they sold the restaurant. So, they left the center panel and the new owners moved/placed it in a new frame (below). Guess everyone else knew the 3 of them didn't get along. Too bad the architects didn't :)

@eatious thanks! remember having a tough time laying out the design until changing the scale between the huge Plaza and the old buildings. by drawing the side panels at a larger scale it made them jump forward and pushed the center design back. at least that was the idea.

Nelson Rockefeller). it only took 2 billion (when a billion was real money) and most of the stone in Vermont...

data.alt: laser engraving designs based p - thoskite | ello

body.data: These are laser engraving designs based on pasta for kitchen cabinet glass doors that are to be made some other day, having just sold the goddamned laser.
The black areas are unengraved and the white is engraved because the laser leaves a frosted appearance (white).
This requires making the design as you see it now to show what it will look like on the glass in front of a dark background (inside of cabinet).
Once the design is finished, the final image the laser uses is inverted so it will engrave only the white areas.

So the laser had to go anyway to help cover some of the losses when Peltagames crashed and burned. But, the real reason is- the sea is calling us to come home. Sometimes making can go places that later you wish you never went. So it makes life a little more exciting, but at a cost… just like a kiss of fire-

data.alt: GIFed box art PELTA TESS, game  - thoskite | ello

body.data: GIFed some box art for PELTA TESS, the last game we made before shutting down. The game fits in a UV printed, wood cigar box.
In the cigar box, there are 4 special squares in 4 different colors that contain 64 pieces each. All of the 256 pieces are cut into 4 different shapes.
The inside borders of the special squares help players start anyone of many possible tessellating patterns that will complete each square.

Have about 40 boxes printed before we sold off the UV printer and the acrylic stock. Unfortunately, didn’t get to laser cut pieces for them. So, there’s only one complete PeltaTESS game in existence at this point.
